Title: Gertrud
Text:
Hopeless romantic Gertrud inhabits a turn-of-the-century milieu of artists and musicians, where she pursues an idealized notion of love that will always elude her. She abandons her distinguished husband and embraces an affair with a young concert pianist, who falls short of her desire for lasting affection. When an old lover returns to her life, fresh disappointments follow, and Gertrud must try to come to terms with¬†reality.
The realization that reality is prismatic, acceptance of reality, and then retaliation against it. Maybe this is the only profound film. Advanced studies for Dreyer‚Äîrigorous in ways one doesn't even know how to particularly articulate. Dreyer's choices of when to edit and when to pan or move the camera at first seem defiantly baffling, until it all starts to form a logic with the narrative. The film has both a simplicity (woman's idealized version of love will always fail her), and yet an intense complexity that it's hard to know where to begin. Paintings are key here‚Äîreflections of narrative, all mainly Renaissance "representational" art, save for that final one of the grotesque woman (her 
Dorian Gray
?). Compositions have a intense stillness to them that registers almost beyond comprehension‚ÄîDan Sallitt pondered after the screening that only Dreyer would pull back the camera‚Ä¶ 
more "This is so often the way with life. You spend so much time waiting for something ‚Äì a person, a feeling, a piece of information ‚Äì that you can‚Äôt quite absorb it when it is in front of you. The hole is so used to being a hole it doesn‚Äôt know how to close itself."
 
- Matt Haig

Title: Satyricon
Text:
After his young lover, Gitone, leaves him for another man, Encolpio decides to kill himself, but a sudden earthquake destroys his home before he has a chance to do so. Now wandering around Rome in the time of Nero, Encolpio encounters one bizarre and surreal scene after¬†another.
Afterthoughts:
 Fellini‚Äôs orgiastic odyssey through Ancient Rome is a sheer, debauched delight.
Gliding seamlessly from one erotic and extravagant episode to the next, Fellini takes us on a richly symbolic journey of sex and violence that beams with colourful sights and sounds, critiquing the consumerist hedonism of capitalist modernity, whilst offering an eccentric look at one of history's most interesting civilisations.
Similarly to the films of Alejandro Jodorowsky, it is a great joy to see Fellini granted all the necessary resources to realise his audacious and ambitious surrealist masterpiece on the large scale it clearly required.
The average ratings for this film are criminally low! Worthy of higher and wider praise for certain. Might fuck around and buy myself a slave twink. If an experiment was conducted consisting in submitting a modest cinema connoisseur to this beautiful and decadently disastrous orgy of anarchic cultural aspects of Rome, perhaps the first name that would pop up to his head was Pasolini. Surprisingly, it isn't. More surprisingly, this rebellious piece of art entered the business before Pasolini's Trilogy of Life. Truth is, Satyricon is the turning point for the legend that Fellini already was before autobiographical memoirs and nostalgia invaded his mind with controversial youth moments added here and there for spicing up his love letters to the city that gave him life and an identity forever.
99/100

Title: Magic

seeing anthony hopkins not old is so fucking weird This film is like a box of chocolates; you never know what to expect. I mean, you have a picture that would normally feature and be made by a low-level actor and director that everyone would probably forget. And yet, you have Richard Attenborough directing a film written by William Goldman, composed by Jerry Goldsmith, and starring a deranged young Anthony Hopkins in a dual role as this pathetic puppeteer and the voice of this diabolical puppet whose banter is all pure gold. It's bizarre, disturbing, and amusing; it's a film that, in a rational world, would never exist, but here it is.
All in all, I'm not sure what more to say; if the cast and crew, as well as the premise of a disturbed guy who utilizes a spooky-looking puppet to offload his homicidal traumas, don't compel you to see this film, I'm not sure what will.

Title: Finding¬†Forrester
Text:
Gus Van Sant tells the story of a young African American man named Jamal who confronts his talents while living on the streets of the Bronx. He accidentally runs into an old writer named Forrester who discovers his passion for writing. With help from his new mentor Jamal receives a scholarship to a private¬†school.
You're the man now, dog. There are directors who always seek to adapt to the genre or style of the film they are directing, and there are directors like Gus Van Sant who are always adapting the films to their own style.
Even though a lot of the story turns out to be predictable and the music is typical of such social melodramas of the era, yet what makes the movie feel so unique is Van Sant's unique approach. You see, even when it falls into some stereotypes, this is a film that is clearly trying to challenge our expectations. There is also the fact that for the most part everything plays in such a soothing and calm manner, that it also does its best‚Ä¶

Title: The Masque of the Red¬†Death
Text:
A European prince terrorizes the local peasantry while using his castle as a refuge against the ‚ÄúRed Death‚Äù plague that stalks the¬†land.
If I was living in the middle of a pandemic I guess I too would simply hide out in Vincent Price's gothic, psychedelic Satan cult castle for rich perverts. Prince Prospero is one of very best Poe performances that Corman and Price conceived of during their run together, primarily due to his almost perfect intersection of aristocratic egotistical elegance (never has a character blatantly loved flamboyant costume dress-up and goofy one-liners and scenery chewing as much as Price clearly did himself) and playfully icky sadism. 
He is not as psychologically tortured or sympathetically guilt-ridden as other Poe protagonists, but simply a man who follows a basic misanthropic idea to its logical conclusion: that if God is dead and moral secular‚Ä¶ 
more As colorfully stunning as just about any Hammer picture of its time, each scene pops vibrantly with beautiful camerawork from Nicholas Roeg, all while Vincent Price achieves the perfect mixture of devilish charm and insidious evil.¬†
This adaptation of Poe‚Äôs short story adds some extra things to the source material but also once again shows the often undervalued directorial efforts of Roger Corman‚Äîwho achieves more with less better than just about anyone. I think

Title: The¬†Producers
Text:

Mel Brooks‚Äô bizarre off the wall style feels so different from other 60s Hollywood comedies, some still struggling to evolve from the screwball genre that worked so well in the 40s. This has elements of those, but incorporated a dark sense of humor that feels very much like the 70s coming on.
Mel Brooks rocket launched his career with this, defining instantly his brand of parody and absurdism that carried him through, and his legendary collaborations with Gene Wilder.
The Springtime For Hitler opening number had me dying. I look forward to revisiting more of Brooks‚Äô works. On one hand, I can't believe that 
The Producers
 came out in 1967.
On the other, well, it actually makes a lot of sense. classic and silly and honest and human. so unpretentious and genuine in a simple but beautiful way. it‚Äôs not perfect at all, it has pacing issues and some scenes are almost too one-note, but the style and the comedic timing are so memorable, beyond nostalgic. I mean, I just cannot see anything at all that I didn‚Äôt love The Reichman Cometh "I never knew that the Third Reich meant Germany! I mean it's just drenched with historical goodies like that..."
Still funny! Really announces itself in the opening office scene where Mostel and Wilder are screaming and hyperventilating like they really mean it. This shit isn't funny to them, which of course makes it 
very
 funny. I'll bet this felt explosive in 1967, when Mel Brooks' sense of humor lived at the exact intersection of the Borscht Belt and the "sick comics" of the late '50s/'60s (your Lenny Bruces, your Mort Sahls, etc).
As director, Brooks doesn't sweat the technical stuff too much.

Title: Ray
Text:
Born on a sharecropping plantation in Northern Florida, Ray Charles went blind at seven. Inspired by a fiercely independent mom who insisted he make his own way, He found his calling and his gift behind a piano keyboard. Touring across the Southern musical circuit, the soulful singer gained a reputation and then exploded with worldwide fame when he pioneered coupling gospel and country¬†together.
I like how Ray goes to rehab and then the movie just...ends. And text tells us "he never did drugs again." It was very bold of the filmmakers to actually go back in time and cast young Ray Charles as himself. Not many filmmakers would take such a risk. Though this musical biopic is a bit overstretched with some flaws, it is just full of energy and love, powered by some fantastic performance from Jamie Foxx and refreshing blues. It addresses the psychological aspects, balancing out both his personal and professional fronts through his musical odyssey in a neat and engaging manner. A good solid watch.

Title: The Loneliness of the Long Distance¬†Runner
Text:

Tony Richardson is arguably responsible for ushering in the British New Wave and then, knowingly or not, ushering it away. Perhaps the moviegoing public could only take so much misery and strife. By 1964, Richardson had gone mainstream and won big with 
Tom Jones
 whilst The Beatles and Bond marked a new direction in British cinema which was vastly more commercial and a lot cheerier. Film historians cite 1964 as the terminus for the British New Wave, and although I disagree, 
Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner
 certainly marks its zenith two years prior.¬†
This picture is a pure encapsulation of what defined the British New Wave of the late 50s/early 60s. The‚Ä¶ 
more One of the many themes running through The Loneliness Of The Long Distance Runner is that, as long as you're adept at a sport of some kind, then the establishment will give you a pass at every turn.
When I went to grammar school, I was a pretty decent cricketer. I bowled medium pace nibblers and was good enough to be on the school squad. Except I chose not to be. Not because I didn't like playing cricket, far from it. I just would rather not spend my Saturdays stood on the playing fields of Greater Manchester, fearful of diving in dog shit trying to stop a boundary. I would much rather stay at home and play on the Commodore‚Ä¶ 
more While Melville, Truffaut, Godard, Rivette, Rohmer, and Chabrol, among others, we're shaping the French Nouvelle Vague, a parallel movement influenced by them was emerging in England as a rebellious response to the narrative artificiality of Hollywood and British dramaturgy. It was characterized by implementing a realistic aesthetic in fiction and documentary films dealing with everyday life and social commitment to the problems of the time, born in the 50s of the last century, the Free Cinema era, of this group highlighted other personalities such as John Schlesinger or Lindsay Anderson, but perhaps the most representative film maybe this one directed by the legendary Tony Richardson.

ridley: AND YOU'LL HEAR IT AGAIN The final 10 minutes feel truly momentous and hardly anything else does. Crowe and Denzel toe-to-toe, trading sweeping proclamations about the past and the future, refugees from their chosen lifestyles connecting to reroute their destinies; Josh Brolin splattering a sun shield with blood after pressing his Smith & Wesson to his chin; Frank Lucas exiting prison to the perfectly synced sound of 1991 Public Enemy, facing a new world order all alone. Title: Miracle¬†Mile
Text:
After 30 years of searching, Harry has finally met the girl of his dreams. Unfortunately, before they even have a chance to go on their first date, Harry intercepts some chilling news: WWIII has begun and nuclear missiles will destroy Los Angeles in less than an¬†hour!
the fact that Mare Winningham and Anthony Edwards got married in real life 33 years later is such an unbelievably perfect grace note to the end of this story. "People are gonna help each other, won't they? I mean, rebuilding things, the survivors I mean."
"I think it's the insects' turn." 84
The hopelessness of 
Miracle Mile
 is constantly at odds with its own romantic idealism, as to suggest that what we yearn to achieve is impossible but there's nothing wrong with trying anyway, even as the reality is damning. Such a balance within a real-time countdown narrative could easily be seen as disjointed, but the horror of the situation is perfectly offset by gestures of humility, the motions that we enact to continue our supposed self-designated purpose. As a glorious neon technical exercise, not to mention scored by Tangerine Dream, this is brilliant, but at its core, the speculative nature is precedent. It lingers long after the final moment - angry and defeated, overcome with emotion.

Title: Weekend
Text:
After a drunken house party with his straight mates, Russell heads out to a gay club. Just before closing time he picks up Glen but what‚Äôs expected to be just a one-night stand becomes something else, something¬†special.
I never learned how to show interest.
When the chemistry is strong, when the performance is strong, between two actors playing people in love, you can put yourself in it. You feel them fumbling emotionally. You feel them exuding affection. You feel them get frustrated. You feel their tenderness. You feel their projections as they try to peel off the surface tension and find the people they are underneath in a scant two days. You feel the empty spaces between them fill up with a cocktail of lust, love, and impossibility. You feel them feeling the stares. 
And here, it's painful to watch. Their relationship is shaped by their environment in ways that confine them, as Glen points out, cements‚Ä¶ 
more Something that I appreciate so much about 
Weekend
 is that it is a definitively, undeniably gay movie that could not be re-written as a heteroromantic film. Not that every gay film 
has
 to justify its existence as distinctly 'gay', but gay love isn't really the same as hetero love and it's important to explore these layers when such love is being explored on film.
Russell is pretty classically romantic. He wants to get married, settle down somewhere, and is shy about displaying his gayness to the world. For him, he's happy to just be happy and doesn't need anything more than that.
Glenn is someone who wants to break boundaries. He doesn't do boyfriends, doesn't want to be tied down‚Ä¶

The only thing more predictable than this high-concept police story is the idea that a year as punishing as 2017 would save the worst for last. Title: What Happened¬†Was‚Ä¶
Text:
Jackie and Michael are coworkers at a large law firm. They decide to meet at Jackie‚Äôs for dinner one¬†night.
'What Happened Was' is far too good to still be so obscure. I can think of few films more deserving of a quality home video release. It is currently available to stream on Prime and a few other services, but it is far from looking or sounding particularly good. Based on Tom Noonan‚Äôs stage play, 'What Happened Was' takes place over the course of a single evening in a New York apartment, where two law firm employees get together for dinner after work. Jackie (Karen Sillas) hosts Michael (Noonan), a gawky paralegal she believes to be the smartest guy in the office. She finds him oddly attractive and appears nervous and very eager to impress him. Michael does come across‚Ä¶ 
more amazing that the two posters in her apartment are MLK Jr and Cats the musical "What's so bad about awkward?" my therapist asked me a few months ago. Well, I've mulled it over for a while, and I can say that awkwardness entails uncertainty. It makes me vulnerable, and that makes me nervous. On the other hand, awkward interactions can hold latent potential. In this movie, two coworkers meet for a dinner of reheated scallops and share a bottle of wine. They chuckle nervously and talk at cross-purposes. It's awkward, which might indicate that their relationship has reached the dangerous place between nothing and something.
The camera reorients itself around the couple, framing them in symmetrical two shots. It pens them within unities of real time and space as if they were rabbits in a‚Ä¶

Title: Gangs of Wasseypur ‚Äì Part¬†1
Text:
In 1970s India, Sardar Khan vows to take revenge on the man who killed his father decades¬†earlier.
There's a throwaway moment here where Sardar Khan tries to kick open a door that opens just by gently pulling it; it's one of the film's several great comic moments, but it also represents the fundamental tragedy fascinating Kashyap here. Indian men constantly exerting force not because they necessarily need to, but because it makes them feel powerful and sexy and in charge of their own destiny. Everyone's vulgar power fantasy is undercut at some turn as a consequence of sociopolitical fact, or their own brutish masculinity, or the sudden realization that not everyone can be Amitabh Bachchan, or simply because the door doesn't open that way. So much more here than the now rote "violence begets violence" of American cable prestige dramas (though its split into an 8 episode "season" on Netflix is further indicative of the thematic overlap this shares with them). A middle class guy named Zeishan Qadri on a random day in the early 2010s knocked on Anurag Kashyap's studio door with a script which had nothing but former's childhood in Dhanbad and Wasseypur locked in it, suggesting the latter to make a movie on the gangster uprising of the pre independent Bihar state.
Anurag Kashyap didn't have any clue whatsoever that a never seen before true story spanning several decades in the enormous runtime of 5 hrs will have so much fan following in the coming years.
Kashyap is an inspired filmmaker and he doesn't feel afraid to reflect the inspiration he takes from many filmmakers in his works. Wasseypur blends the Scoresisan narrative structure and absurdity of Tarantinoish‚Ä¶

Title: The Roaring¬†Twenties
Text:
After World War I, Armistice Lloyd Hart goes back to practice law, former saloon keeper George Hally turns to bootlegging, and out-of-work Eddie Bartlett becomes a cab driver. Eddie builds a fleet of cabs through delivery of bootleg liquor and hires Lloyd as his lawyer. George becomes Eddie‚Äôs partner and the rackets flourish until love and rivalry¬†interfere.
Ripped from the headlines of the turbulent era between the Great War and the Great Depression, this dynamic, nostalgia-tinged crime drama balances tommy-gun action with epic historical sweep. Legends James Cagney and Humphrey Bogart star as army buddies whose fortunes rise and fall as their fates intersect, first in a foxhole on the front lines of World War I, then in Manhattan‚Äôs Prohibition-era underworld. Directed by Hollywood master Raoul Walsh, and based on a story by prolific journalist turned screenwriter and producer Mark Hellinger, The Roaring Twenties brought to a close the celebrated Warner Bros. gangster cycle of the 1930s, and it remains one of the greatest and most influential crime films of all time.
Our edition arrives on February 27, 2024. To learn more or pre-order, visit 
 Criterion.com. Arriving at tail-end of the trend of prohibition-era gangster films and intended as something of a goodbye Walsh applies a sophisticated, freewheeling energy composed of kinetic camera moves, elaborate montages and bursts of ruthless violence to tackle the entire decade‚Äîfrom WWI to the great depression to FDR and the end of prohibition. and in the process he essentially invents the Scorsese model of tracing the crime underworld through the passage of time, minute gang politics and the hangout, low-level POV of those who find themselves spending their lifetime in its historical orbit. Just the best! Bogart had appeared in a number of the Warner gangster films as a side character by this point but this is the one to finally‚Ä¶ 
more He used to be a big shot.
-Panama Smith
The film can probably best be described as a fast paced gangster epic. The story is truly epic in scope as it starts out in World War I and makes it's way to the early 30s covering everything from prohibition, the stock market crash and the great depression. This would be the last film 
James Cagney
 and 
Humphrey Bogart
 made together.
This would also mark the last gangster film 
Cagney
 would star in before swearing off the genre. He would actually go a decade before returning to it in the legendary 
White Heat
, coincidentally by the same director:

. The gangster genre was winding down to make way for film-noir,‚Ä¶

Title: The Wandering¬†Earth
Text:
When the Sun begins to expand in such a way that it will inevitably engulf and destroy the Earth in a hundred years, united mankind finds a way to avoid extinction by propelling the planet out of the Solar System using gigantic engines, moving it to a new home located four light years away, an epic journey that will last thousands of¬†years.
I'm weirdly proud of China for being able to make their own Geostorm. Billed as China‚Äôs first true sci-fi blockbuster, Frant Gwo‚Äôs ridiculously profitable (and borderline unwatchable) ‚ÄúThe Wandering Earth‚Äù tells the story of a cursed future in which the sun has become unstable, and humanity‚Äôs only hope for survival are the 10,000 jet engines strong enough to dislodge our planet from its orbit and launch us toward a solar system that‚Äôs 4.2 light-years away.
Currently the second-highest grossing movie in Chinese box office history, and now dumped on Netflix without fanfare, Gwo‚Äôs film also tells the story of another cursed future ‚Äî one that presents a more clear and present danger ‚Äî in which the spectacle required to sustain popular cinema becomes so large that the industry congeals into a worldwide monoculture‚Ä¶ 
more Even more absurd than most Emmerich disasterpieces, with the DIRTY DOZEN-esque band of misfits on a massive CG-enhanced suicide space mission of ARMAGEDDON mixed in, and honestly it's as tasty as that sounds, all enlivened by a pretty refreshing spirit of collectivism. This really does earn its deep silliness.

Title: Ghostwatch
Text:
For Halloween 1992, the BBC decides to broadcast an investigation into the supernatural, hosted by TV chat-show legend Michael Parkinson. Parky (assisted by Mike Smith, Sarah Greene & Craig Charles) and a camera crew attempt to discover the truth behind the most haunted house in Britain. This ground-breaking live television experiment does not go as planned,¬†however.
The ominous cupboard under the stairs being called 'the glory hole' never gets old. People with a time machine:
-‚ÄúI am your granddaughter/son‚Äù
-‚ÄúReally?‚Äù
Me with a time machine:
I‚Äôm going to go back in time to October 31st 1992 to watch the original broadcast of Ghostwatch 1992. I would give several essential parts of my body to get the opportunity to travel back to that year. Not so I can be 17 again, but so my 17 year old self could have the chance to watch Ghostwatch live.
In what is perhaps one of the best TV pranks ever, the usually rather reserved BBC decides to produce an absolutely terrifying fake live television event investigating a haunted house. Having British TV icon Parky host the proceedings is one of many flashes of brilliance, giving it a sense of realism and importance. Surely good old Parky wouldn't want us 'to have sleepless nights'.
The true star here and the main reason this works so well is writer‚Ä¶

Title: An American¬†Crime
Text:

Title: Fort¬†Apache
Text:
Owen Thursday sees his new posting to the desolate Fort Apache as a chance to claim the military honour which he believes is rightfully his. Arrogant, obsessed with military form and ultimately self-destructive, he attempts to destroy the Apache chief Cochise after luring him across the border from Mexico, against the advice of his¬†subordinates.
"No Questions." Constant groupings into Ford's "Calvary Trilogy" (which consists of this and two significantly weaker films) often hides the fact that this is one of Ford's most ambitious and complex works. Radical both then and today for its equation of blind submission to authority with suicide. What a fine double bill this would make with Mizoguchi's "The 47 Ronin"! One of the most astonishing things: in the final two minutes Ford demonstrates his understanding that the basics of cinema is not story and character, but composition, sound and montage. After John Wayne "prints the legend," Ford has him wear Fonda's hat, and then repeats shots of the regiment marching off and the women watching them. By itself, this would‚Ä¶ 
more Every time I see this, I think 'Surely this must be Ford's best film.'
But I say the same about a half dozen other films.
Interesting compare/contrast with Raoul Walsh's Custer film 
They Died with their Boots On
. Walsh takes a real figure and makes him heroic, entirely in the face of history, Ford takes a fictional figure and matches him to anti-heroic history.
Thursday doesn't hate Indians, he just sees them as less than human. Barely a step above the Irishmen he finds himself surrounded by on the frontier. He despises the corrupt Indian agent, but treats him with more respect than anyone else he meets because his title gives him a class status the others can't match. Even‚Ä¶ 
more *Was a 
67
, now an 
85
*
Struggled with this film initially when I watched it last year. But upon revisit, this is a clear landmark for John Ford, both in its psychological complexity and the examination of the rituals that bind the communities of his films. Not only does 
Fort Apache

Title: Drunken Master¬†II
Text:
Returning home with his father after a shopping expedition, Wong Fei-Hong is unwittingly caught up in the battle between foreigners who wish to export ancient Chinese artifacts and loyalists who don‚Äôt want the pieces to leave the country. Fei-Hong must fight against the foreigners using his Drunken Boxing style, and overcome his father‚Äôs antagonism as¬†well.
I think you could reasonably say that the Golden Age of the kung fu film began in 1967 with 
The One-Armed Swordsman
, reached its classical perfection with 1978's 
The 36th Chamber of Shaolin
 and saw its last gasp with 1994's 
Drunken Master II
. The common denominator is Lau Kar-leung: he was Chang Cheh's action director on the first, directed his brother Gordon Liu in the second and co-starred and co-directed with the genre's longest lasting, most successful icon, Jackie Chan, on the third.
That this film remains unavailable in its original form is a travesty, a crime against cinema. Took my dad (who had never before seen a Jackie Chan film) to see this at the Princess Cinema, an art house in Waterloo, Ontario.
Think of how difficult it would be to do a single backflip. Now imagine, like, 15 uninterrupted minutes of incredible feats of physical agility. I actually think it's possible to underrate the fight scenes in this movie because they are so dense with 
stuff
 that the human eye and brain can barely take it all in. A few thoughts:
1. This film rips cultural appropriation, colonialism, and the British in general a new asshole. It makes direct reference to it in the plot and with some exposition, but it drives the point home by making the villains as sneeringly "British" as possible. I'm sure it rankles a few colonial feathers, but whatever. That's what you get for conquering, enslaving, and generally being jerks to the entire world. 
2. The final fight sequence lasts something like three years, but it's entirely worth it. Jackie Chan's physical performance is a wonder. Between the flames and the men kicking in suits and...
3. ...Jackie Chan weaponizing "the worm" dance, the combat is as good as any dance sequence you can name.
4. But there should have been more drunken fighting to earn that title.

Title: Red¬†State

 - Joe Keenan
There's something about this film that hopelessly endearing. It's like a baby being birthed into the world; confused, lost, messy and gory from all of the afterbirth that's come after it, but ever so lovable. You think that's a weird analogy? 
Red State
 is a weird film.
Beginning as an immature and unfunny teen comedy, turning into a religious torture-porn movie, then twisting itself into a siege movie and ending a religious satire that leaves a massive grin plastered across your face at the end of a relatively short 80 minutes, it's probably one of the most schizophrenic movies of all time.‚Ä¶

Title: I Am¬†Cuba
Text:
Four vignettes on the lives of the Cuban people in the pre-revolutionary era. In Havana, Maria is ashamed when a man she loves discovers how she makes a living. We're losing our shit for CGI long takes when this movie exists? Capitalism now benefits from having successfully colonized much of the world, and I'd wager the vast majority of users on this site cannot even truly comprehend an alternative ideology outside of theoreticals (me included ofc). Slow and introspective, this is the seed of a violent legacy and a stark reminder of how isolating it can be. Title: The Man Who Knew Too¬†Little
Text:
An American gets a ticket for an audience participation game in London, then gets involved in a case of mistaken identity. As an international plot unravels around him, he thinks it‚Äôs all part of the¬†act.
Just when I thought I had seen every Bill Murray I find some random 90's comedy on VHS for 25 cents at a thrift store. 
So when VHS movie night with the squad rolls around, I think this might be our greatest discovery in quite some time. Probably one of the best 90's comedies that no one has ever heard of. 
What seems to be another mistaken identity, wrong place wrong time comedy is perfectly executed. What makes this so great is Bill Murrays character never catches on. Most of these things break in the second half because the character realizes they are a part of the conspiracy and try to get out. Not the case here. It's just Bill Murray having loads of fun for 90 minutes. The inherent darkness of every character seeing Bill Murray as a full-blown Richard T. Joker psychopath really makes this silly motherfucker fly. I did not expect to enjoy this film as much as I did. Then again, perhaps it's more the bottle of white wine I've been working my way through?
The incompetent/ignorant spy story has been done so many times before, most recently, I think, with 
Johnny English
 (which I also enjoy). Bill Murray's humour fits effortlessly into the role of Wallace Ritchie, an accident-prone Blockbuster retailer who thinks he's taking part in an audience-participation theatre event. It's nice to see so many familiar faces showing up along the way, but it's Murray who single-handedly carries the show. That man can do no wrong!

Title: Theatre of¬†Blood
Text:
A Shakespearean actor takes poetic revenge on the critics who denied him¬†recognition.
Imagine the thrill of getting to kill your biggest critics. Now imagine that as Vincent Price.
Forever my favorite genre actor‚ÄîI‚Äôve seen a solid 50+ of his movies and haven‚Äôt seen a bad performance yet. He‚Äôs so deliciously devious in this I can‚Äôt help but sit here and watch with a giant shit eating grin on my face. Yeah, I‚Äôm sure Shakespeare would‚Äôve appreciated his works being endlessly adapted into both Oscar bait and genre films year in and year out (I mean, who doesn‚Äôt love a nice dry hand job from Kenneth Branagh every now and then?), but you know what he would‚Äôve loved even more? Vincent Price using his plays as an excuse to put on an absolute masterclass in hamminess as a petty, slighted thespian who slices & stabs & drowns & force-feeds & electrocutes his critics to death with surprisingly legit blood and gore in a dark comedy revenge tale homage to the creativity and uniqueness of Shakespeare‚Äôs own penchant for grisly murder scenes. Who needs another black-and-white overly faithful take on Macbeth when you can have Vinnie P and a young smokeshow Diana Rigg graphically cutting a dude‚Äôs heart out of his chest?
Underrated Movies that More People Should See The genius of the film is recognizing that Shakespeare‚Äôs plays are stocked with heinous and gruesome scenes; however, they usually took place off stage in Jacobean times and were stagey and anemically filmed on the screen prior to 1971 (Polanski‚Äôs 
Macbeth
.) What would it be like if Hector was really dragged tied to the tail a horse, or Caesar slashed down by a mob of amateurs, or if Iago had extracted a pound of flesh from Antonio? It‚Äôs a testimony to the infinite fungibility of Shakespeare that he can be used as the basis for a thespian gore-fest. 
Vincent Price is at his absolute best as a crazed Prospero with a cast of drunken minion Calibans and a homicidal Cordelia,‚Ä¶

Title: Far from¬†Heaven
Text:

Title: The Draughtsman‚Äôs¬†Contract
Text:
A young artist is commissioned by the wife of a wealthy landowner to make a series of drawings of the estate while her husband is¬†away.
This is just an hour and 45 minutes of exquisitely framed baroque insult-hurling with a slight surrealist bent. I'm absolutely here for it. Aristocratic verbal slapfights. Artful social engineering. Lush visual presentation. Layer upon layer of subtle story telling (there is even a side-plot murder mystery embedded within). 
If you watch this movie without paying attention, it may seem like a cluster of high society ponces desperately trying to out ponce each other. But it has much more going on. Every interaction represents a risky social maneuver for someone. Sometimes boldly announcing their intentions, other times hopping to sell a lie. At all times hoping to gain advantage or ameliorate wounded reputation.
And it's all done from within the rigid confines of the aristocratic social code. From behind exaggerated period costumes. Within the idyllic walls of a country estate. People behaving like statues, statues behaving like people. 
A detail rich film that rewards multiple viewings. One of the best films I have seen in a while. ‚ÄúYou sound as impotent by day as you perform by night.‚Äù
Peter Greenaway‚Äôs first traditional narrative film 
The Draughtsman‚Äôs Contract
¬†is a stylish and clever period drama, clearly drawing inspiration from 
Barry Lyndon 
in its regal 17/18th century imagery but with its own uniquely compelling characters and biting sense of humour. It‚Äôs biggest strength is in writing -¬†heavy on dialogue but consistently entertaining with back and forth lines of intricately worded, archaic insults, and an elaborate story that‚Äôs as flowery and emphatic as the characters themselves; maybe sometimes being a little difficult to follow if you‚Äôre not paying full attention but fascinating nonetheless. I‚Äôm a fan of period movies in general even though they are kind of hit or miss, but this is one definitely done right; original, delightful, and surely having its own influence over films that succeeded it.

Title: Wonderstruck
Text:
The story of a young boy in the Midwest is told simultaneously with a tale about a young girl in New York from fifty years ago as they both seek the same mysterious¬†connection.
Todd Haynes‚Äô films, intellectually rigorous and often profoundly moving, are fractured stories in which alienated, beautiful characters try to find love (or a certain likeness) in the delicate folds of real life. All of this is made possible by a cinema in which aesthetics assume religious force, culture exists on a continuum, and art has a memory.
In other words, don‚Äôt be fooled that his latest feature is a hyper-faithful adaptation of a half-illustrated children‚Äôs novel by ‚ÄúThe Invention of Hugo Cabret‚Äù author Brian Selznick ‚Äî ‚ÄúWonderstruck‚Äù is nothing if not a Todd Haynes movie. And it‚Äôs an exquisite one, at that. Fresh off the greatest triumph of his career (that would be ‚ÄúCarol‚Äù), Haynes is still operating near the peak of his powers, returning to Cannes with an immaculately crafted fable about the ways in which people of all ages learn to break out of their bodies and connect with the world.
READ THE FULL REVIEW ON INDIEWIRE There‚Äôs something so undeniably beautiful about this movie. Maybe it‚Äôs the way Todd Haynes loves film, and you can feel it in every shot, in every edit, in every line of dialogue. Or maybe it‚Äôs the score, carrying the movie in every scene as if it were its own character. Maybe it‚Äôs even the kids, who are just that, and make the film seem so child like and wondrous.
But maybe it‚Äôs just my brother.

Title: Coma
Text:
When relatively healthy patients begin having ‚Äòcomplications‚Äô during simple operations and ending up in comas, a concerned doctor defies her male superiors when she suspects a secret¬†plot.
70‚Äôs paranoia techno thrillers give me the most anxiety. Nightmare stuff, the kind of thing that makes me fidget in my seat and gives me gooseflesh. The queasiness of liminality, of the inbetween-spaces, of involution and convolution, of wake and sleep, life and death, of public and private, Coma is operative in those places, in that where and when. Arriving at a time when female agency in traditionally male-dominated professions was met with tremendous backlash, condescension, gaslighting, second-guessing, Coma's Genevieve Bujold is a heroine beset by these forces, yet undeterred by them. She is a doctor in a medical system slowly awakening to its ability to reap the benefits of its volume, its monopoly, its government contracts, its grotesque specialization, during a time when human life can be preserved and extended, but at what cost, and by what means, and to what end? Michael Crichton's career‚Ä¶

Title: A New¬†Leaf
Text:

52 project: 42/52 An absolutely toxic screwball that doesn't so much update the genre for a nihilistic and self-absorbed era as demonstrate that the genre had beaten society to that punch by a good 40 years. Matthau is a collection of faces housed in a shambling figure, a trickster god finally outsmarted after millennia of existence by his own profligacy. The montage of him morosely bidding farewell to the trappings of his life as he slowly drives around town in his collapsing Ferrari is just about as British as American class comedy can get, and Henry's transition into a Bluebeard/Verdoux grotesque only completes the black joke. At the other end is May herself, who manages to play both the leads in Bringing Up‚Ä¶ 
more "Excuse me, you're not by any chance related to the Boston Hitlers?" So funny. While this may be her directorial debut it feels like such a perfect bundle of everything I love about Elaine May. Hilarious, clever, a little sad, and different. So different. I'm not alone when I say for the hundredth time that May was way ahead of her time, but even if she was making movies today (which apparently she might be doing soon?) nobody could come close to replicating her work. Heavens! Feel like I‚Äôve seen a million imitations of this movie but none that feel so chaotic and ‚Äúunfinished‚Äù in it‚Äôs plotting. But I think I mean that in a good way? Matthau‚Äôs character is a sociopath, he has no comeuppance, Henrietta never learns of his scheme, and he makes a sudden about face at the end for reasons I don‚Äôt think I understand. It‚Äôs an odd couple pairing without a straight man. And it‚Äôs so funny. "You have preserved in your own lifetime sir, a way of life that was dead before you were born.". The perfect 70s counterpoint to 30's class screwball comedy. she‚Äôs so me (autistic and highly susceptible to falling in love in 3 days) He was a broke asexual sociopath, she was an immensely wealthy autistic bimbo, could I make it anymore obvious? Absolutely brilliant farce. How did I go this long before seeing it? Horrible rich guy goes bankrupt throwing his money around too frivolously, so he marries a rich social misfit to support his lifestyle, with plans to murder her for money down the line. And yet... this is a love story. Billy Wilder would be proud. "Marriage is the only way to acquire property without labor."

Something in this image of a foreign power invading this unspoiled land, stripping it of its natural resources, and leaving it a smoldering ruin, feels like a metaphor for the way Hollywood strip-mines famous brands for content. Even though 
The Legend of Tarzan
 doesn‚Äôt directly continue any specific movie, it‚Äôs structured just like a legacyquel; it‚Äôs trying to find a way to make a very old concept feel new again. But some concepts resist modernization despite their creators‚Äô best intentions. And sometimes the only way to make something truly new is to make something truly new.

Title: Hook
Text:
The boy who wasn‚Äôt supposed to grow up‚ÄîPeter Pan‚Äîdoes just that, becoming a soulless corporate lawyer whose workaholism could cost him his wife and kids. During his trip to see Granny Wendy in London, the vengeful Capt. Hook kidnaps Peter‚Äôs kids and forces Peter to return to¬†Neverland.
One of those rare cinematic curiosities where you can tell instantly how old someone was when they first saw the film based upon their reaction to it today.
It goes like this: almost without exception, those who first saw 
Hook
 as an adult will‚Äîby virtue of being a horrible grown-up‚Äîcompletely and utterly loathe the film, detesting everything it represents about cinema today. They will deride 
Hook
 as bloated and indulgent; treacly Spielbergian sentimentality run amuck; and, worst of all‚Äî
*gasp*
‚Äîtotally made-up, phooey, ridiculous make-believe kid nonsense. (Don't feel bad for them; that's just typical of grown-ups.)
Meanwhile, those of us who first saw 
Hook
 as kids... well, the truth of it is we can't help but adore the utter crap out‚Ä¶ 
more One of the most endearing and likable bad movies I've seen :) There's a lot to dislike about this movie‚Äì so much so that apparently Spielberg doesn't even love it himself‚Äì but I think it's magical. Julia Roberts having fun! Incredible production design that feels like a Universal Studios live show! Outstanding cameos! (Glenn Close?? Phil Collins?? David Crosby?? Jimmy Buffet?? George Lucas and Carrie Fisher for some reason????) An all-time iconic performance from Dustin Hoffman! If I had just one (1) more beer in me, the scene where the little boy says "Oh there you are Peter" would've brought a tear to my eye. Spielberg brings a sense of fantasy and whimsy to so many other projects, it's great to just see him take that style right to a straight-up fantasy.‚Ä¶

Title: The New¬†World
Text:
A drama about explorer John Smith and the clash between Native Americans and English settlers in the 17th¬†century.
When aliens invade earth and unforeseeably exterminate our entire race in the passing of a millisecond with their incomprehensible bio-weaponry, the only human being that they're going to spare is Terrence Malick. The fourth movie in my Terrence Malick screening series, and maybe my sentimental favorite Malick film. 
We watched the Extended Cut, which is absolutely my preferred version. This gentle, deeply felt epic impresses me more each time I revisit it. What appears to be a deceptively simple story hides fathoms of complexities, all anchored on a perfect performance by then 14-year-old actress Q'orianka Kilcher. This is a movie about discovery, love, fate, the inevitable tidal wave of history, and - ultimately - an aching regret. There are few lines as perfectly written and acted as "I may have sailed past them". 
My little screening group is becoming more polarized with each Malick film we screen, which is no surprise. While‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Kid
Text:
A tramp cares for a boy after he‚Äôs abandoned as a newborn by his mother. Later the mother has a change of heart and aches to be reunited with her¬†son.
In many ways, perhaps the sweetest film ever made. But The Kid still, like all of Chaplin's films, is a very sad one. There's still barely enough to eat, authorities still antagonize only the proletarian classes, the "proper care and attention" of an orphanage only causes social disruption. Even as charming as the window breaking sequence is, the Tramp and the Kid have to resort to illegal work in order to make enough money to afford to eat. The Welfare Officer refuses to even speak to the Tramp, and speaks to him through a surrogate, in the Tramp's own home.

Title: Strike
Text:
Workers in a factory in pre-revolutionary Russia go on strike and are met by violent¬†suppression.
More modern than any film I saw in 2018: it's not enough to show the abuses of the systematic, or merely depict that it exists - you have to see its intricacies and functions. Because then otherwise you're just fighting against thin-air. Notwithstanding that one has to be almost supernaturally talented for a film this brilliant to be their first (at this point I'd argue that Eisenstein is the only genius that cinema produced, but that's for another write-up), you can't show these functions with the traditional western protagonist system - the canon itself is part of the oppression. Not that the maneuver is reactionary: by ditching the protagonist, or characters, or "story", we can get a direct and immediate‚Ä¶ 
more join a union! still feels like the future of cinema, both technically and politically, even after almost a hundred years. makes you wonder what can still be accomplished with a camera. 85/100
Suffering in layers ramping and stuttering through time; rhythmic and formally confrontational to the point of exhaustion. Eisenstein utilizes Montage as an intellectual, historical springboard, but there's still the lingering horror within the graphic nature of the cuts. Edits as varied, mathematical calculations of terror and breathtaking jolts. Prettyyyyy fuckin' Major.

That's not how rock-paper-scissors works Imagine if Bu√±uel started a film and Peckinpah finished it. This would probably be that. Given that I just watched a harrowing denouncement of militarism, patriotism, and the death penalty, it's a bit weird to find myself laughing through a violent, pitched battle at a boarding school. But here I am. While this is pretty clearly an indictment of a sort of school I will never experience (thank god), what struck me most about this film was actually the way they captured the teenage experience. Frustration, rebellion, camaraderie, prurience, and angst play out in both realistic and surreal moments, culminating in that violent exchange of automatic gunfire that is horrifyingly satisfying in context.

Little morbid fun fact aside, this was a pretty good film starring some icons of the early horror genre, namely Boris Karloff as this grave robber who supplies corpses for Henry Daniell‚Äôs medical school, but him being Boris Karloff, a grave robber, of course there‚Äôs something even shadier and f‚Äîed up going on. The two are pretty good together and the dynamic and gradual antagonism between the two and how it all eventually unravels make for some suspenseful moments that Wise knows how‚Ä¶

Title: Death¬†Wish

The politics of this movie were very distasteful in my opinion. I try to give a star rating based on the quality of the film and not my moral objections, but it was hard to separate in this case. He is shooting to kill anyone‚Ä¶

Love this sicko movie with its dirty bleak 70‚Äôs vibes as well as Winner‚Äôs tight (and undervalued) direction, and Bronson‚Äôs 20 year dedication to the role of judge, jury, and executioner in a franchise that gets wilder with each entry.

Title: Hope¬†Floats
Text:
Birdee Pruitt has been humiliated on live television by her best friend, Connie, who‚Äôs been sleeping with Birdee‚Äôs husband, Bill. Birdee tries starting over with her daughter, Bernice, by returning to her small Texas hometown, but she‚Äôs faced with petty old acquaintances who are thrilled to see Birdee unhappy ‚Äì except for her friend Justin. As he helps Birdee get back on her feet, love begins to¬†blossom.
So does shit. that little girl cried so much in this movie omg I'm exhausted hadn't seen this in 10+ years, i forgot how painfully sad it sometimes is, how even the corniest melodramatic moments have such darkness underneath...i'm still slightly uncomfortable with it's vague "snap out of it" view of depression, but i feel like everyone's happy-ish ending is well earned, and it's more about the multi-generational mother/daughter relationships than the heartbreak and romance, and how women react to their relationships with men instead of the men themselves. the ending is tidy on the surface but still unsure, only leaving the possibility for happiness open, and i love that it's willing to be messier than other rom-coms. maybe because i love spending time in smithville but the dreamy soap-opera haze and soft colors and small town quirkiness and the little touches of magical realism are so comforting to me...it's so dorky but i feel like it really captures a lot of the barely explainable instinctual reasons why i love texas.

Title: Unbreakable
Text:
An ordinary man makes an extraordinary discovery when a train accident leaves his fellow passengers dead ‚Äî and him unscathed. The answer to this mystery could lie with the mysterious Elijah Price, a man who suffers from a disease that renders his bones as fragile as¬†glass.
So thematically on point most of the shots of Bruce Willis are long 
unbroken
 takes. 100
Watching this for the umpteenth viewing, I couldn't help but focus on how every scene, set-up, narrative development, choice of color and mood and music, feels fresh. Even the most rudimentary moments are captured by M. Night Shyamalan's determination of form. Just take a look at the opening, with the birth of Mr. Glass, as Shyamalan captures the disorientation and confusion with the help of two mirrors and a floaty handheld long-take. Following that, the camera moving back and forth between the space of two seats on the train, or the durational tension of David Dunn waking up after the accident, with a fellow passenger slowly dying in the foreground. And that's just the beginning. By the time we‚Ä¶ 
more I love how uninterested this film is in keeping its symbolism subliminal. Shoot Glass through glass in every scene, give the everyday superhero an everyday uniform with a big SECURITY logo on the back, make it a poncho to block water after establishing his weakness as water, compose your shot like a comic panel and deliver a line like ‚Äúlife doesn‚Äôt have to fit into little boxes that were drawn for it‚Äù before moving the camera in a way that becomes a fundamentally cinematic language.¬†
‚Äú
This one has a surprise ending!
‚Äù
‚Äú
The thing to notice about this piece, the thing that makes it very, very special, is its realistic depiction of its figures.
‚Äù
What else is there to say? Such raw pining for fulfillment here from everyone, sold on every conceivable level.

Title: The¬†Mastermind
Text:
In a sedate corner of Massachusetts circa 1970, an unemployed carpenter turned amateur art thief plans his first big heist. When things go haywire, his life¬†unravels.
Kelly Reichardt has done it* again!
* It = Crafted a quiet, observant piece about an unhappy American drifter looking for something that isn‚Äôt there. Reichardt said in a Q&A that there‚Äôs ‚Äúa little Warren Oates‚Äù in Josh O‚ÄôConnor and that makes me happy and I wish I‚Äôd thought of that. Understated might be an understatement. To fully appreciate much of what Reichardt usually (but especially here) you have to understand how her deconstruction of narratives relates to her deconstruction of masculine tropes. 
A deadbeat dad tries to escape his feeling that he was "meant for greater things" by casting himself as a real life character in the plot of a genre film, all Reichardt does is have show us (with a sort of wry smile) how that would probably actually play out. To defy the plot convention is to defy the masculine hubris. 
What I appreciate about Reichardt's cuts to the bone of her characters is that it isn't done in a mean-spirited way but instead with both tenderness and firmness. 
Also it's just funny and a good time. 
Full review in my coverage of Cannes Week 2. The dishevelled and disappointing Josh O‚ÄôConnor cinematic universe is alive and well!

Title: Drunken¬†Master

After getting into trouble, a mischievous young man is sent to train under a brutal, but slovenly old beggar, who teaches him the secret of the Drunken¬†Fist.
In the english dub of this Jackie Chan says, "I will beat the ass off of you. You will be a man with no ass" to Tiger Leg as an insult. 
Motherfucking cinema, y'all! I'm breaking my rule and not reviewing both times I watched this film.
I watched this on Friday night, and thought it was alright - some great fights, but nothing really stood out.
But I knew I was missing something, and I immediately turned on the commentary, which I finished the next day. The DVD commentary is by 
Ric Meyers
, author of 
Great Martial Arts Movies
 and a friend of Jackie Chan, and 
Jeff Yang
, author of several books including co-writer of Jackie Chan's autobiography. It provided a lot of much-needed context, and it ended with me absolutely loving this film.
A few of my favorite things I learned, which helped me to really appreciate the film - 
Drunken Master
‚Ä¶ 
more Drunken ballet. Historically exceptional choreography. Character and story delivered through action (fights establish his sense of place: first is two great warriors against each other to set upper limit, second he beats his teacher to show he's talented, third he is beaten by his aunt to show he's not invincible, so that by the fourth we're rooting for him and get to enjoy his abilities as he defends a helpless old man). Journey from dishonorable mischievous jokester to honorable mischievous jokester via the path of alcohol. Unbeatable fight scene to not-fight scene ratio (13 in 111 minutes). My new favorite from Jackie Chan.

Title: World on a¬†Wire
Text:
Cybernetics engineer Fred Stiller uncovers a massive corporate conspiracy involving a virtual reality computer¬†project.
Cinematic paranoiac, the great philosophical science fiction mindfuck noir of 1973. As far as connecting with me mentally, this is right in my wheelhouse and pulverizes all the ‚Äònot for me‚Äô slop movies I‚Äôve been suffocated by over the last few weeks here in weirdo 2020.¬†
Even better on a revisit. I fell asleep during 
The Matrix
. Its themes seemed to me, at the time of its release, more or less just trite ideas that I had already read about in various intro philosophy texts and whatnot, and the areas it touched on were never my areas of interest in philosophy anyway. It muddled its religious undertones, and the ethical questions were given short shrift. Fifteen years later, I watched a movie nearly twice as long, which eschews action in favor of psychological intensity, and tackles many--but not all--of the same questions. 
It was much better this time around.
The first and best difference is aesthetic. Fassbinder has created a science fiction world that looks schlubby. It's populated by suits and‚Ä¶ 
more Fassbinder's science-fiction/noir hybrid was really years ahead of its time. Not only in its ideas but in its aesthetic as well. This was such an obvious influence on 
The Matrix
. The Wachowski sisters even modeled the "what does chicken really taste like" scene after a sequence included here.
Its 3,5 hour runtime might deter some modern day viewers from watching it, but they should at least give it a chance, because it's a very rewarding watch.

Title: The Naked¬†City
Text:
After a former model is drowned in her bathtub, Detective James Halloran and Lieutenant Dan Muldoon attempt to piece together her¬†murder.
What an idea to shoot a noir on the rough streets of New York?
Pieces of this film feel like they're ready for the 70s. I wonder if William Friedkin was inspired at all by this film in making The French Connection, especially with the cop chases on the subway. They make it very clear upfront that this was shot mostly on the actual streets of New York, something which would have been very rare in the 40s. Given how expensive and immobile camera equipment was, it was hardly practical to shoot on location, but in a noir about a dirty city, this technique works extremely well. Especially as they are emphasizing how amoral its citizens are.

Another Earth is a fascinating movie because eliminating the science fiction element of the story changes almost nothing at the level of narrative. Rhoda could have won a trip to Wisconsin and most of what goes on would still make sense. But what does change is the emotional and thematic depth of what happens, and I think this is how it works best. What's great about it is that, like the best science fiction, it uses this fantastical addition in order to explore the protagonist's conflict in a way that wouldn't be possible otherwise.
The problem is that it doesn't seem to know where it wants to go in the final act and removes any‚Ä¶ 
more This was a weak attempt at mixing science fiction and drama. Both angles did not work for me and I felt both were underdeveloped. The drama of the car crash and Rhoda's relationship with the father who survived the crash was unoriginal and sappy. The science fiction aspect of a second earth right next to our own is an interesting idea, but the execution was lacking at best. Some shots of having the planet in the background worked well, but overall I could not take the science nor the drama seriously. Despite the weak script and plot I found Brit Marling, quite good and convincing. The wise old sage in the form of a blind Indian janitor was cringeworthy though. Someday maybe someone will love me as much as Brit Marling loves space So, this is my favourite film but I don't think I've properly gone into why I love it so much. Because of this, I decided to rewatch it tonight and try to do a good enough review that explains why this is such an amazing film. 
On the eve of a discover of an Earth-like planet, Rhoda (Brit Marling) is out celebrating when she drunkenly crashes her car and kills two people. Four years later, Rhoda leaves prison and cross paths with John (William Mapother), the man whose life she ripped apart in the car accident. 
This still remains such a clever take on the admittedly overdone premise. The writing is well paced and tackles big themes like grief, regret‚Ä¶

Title: Queen¬†Christina
Text:
Popular monarch Queen Christina of Sweden must choose between love and loyalty to her nation when she unexpectedly falls for a Spanish¬†envoy.
Omg there was only one bed Two kisses and a crossdressing sequence were enough. To any queer woman, Christina could not be more queer, even if she does spend most of the film in love with a man. To any trans person, Christina is a fountain of dysphoric behaviors and triggers. This film, with its tragic hetero-romance, is as openly queer as it probably could be. Two kisses, and a crossdressing sequence. It somehow manages to convincingly have two women be in love, and two men, but with only three characters, because subtext can isolate moments and spin them into whole universes. In reality, she was in love with a woman and left not for a man but for herself. Hollywood tries in their own ways to honor that, but it's still laden with this unnecessary connection. (The film itself, all massive old Hollywood-built sets and snowy landscapes and that low angle on the coronation scene is just stunning, truly stunning.)

Rather, we see the beginnings here of his late style: total didactic turned into moving poetry. Title: Six Men Getting¬†Sick
Text:
Lynch‚Äôs first film project consists of a loop of six people vomiting projected on to a special sculptured screen featuring twisted three-dimensional¬†faces.
My approach to avant garde cinema has always been not to let it bug me if I don't get it; the visual experience is more important than the theme in some ways. That's counter to my approach to pretty much everything else, but when something is oblique or abstract, it becomes like God. I can't prove she exists, I can't prove he doesn't. Why worry? So I watch and see what happens. If nothing happens, then at least I have the imagery to hold onto. This is all to say that David Lynch's animated short left me with some striking, disturbing images to hold onto. The first time I tried to spot out the faces. I spotted out 5, and then they vomited.
The second time I was disturbed by the red color, and kept thinking about why it highlights only the faces at the left. I got interrupted by the time they all vomited.
The third time my mind subliminally perceived the word "SICK" two times, but couldn't read the word clearly. I got mad, so I decided to spot the 6th face. It was formed by the 4th and 6th face, so it was really the 5th. The red shot assaulted me again, and then I saw how their organs were filled with blood before they all vomited.
The fourth time I tried‚Ä¶ 
more The title is not misleading.

Title: Smoke
Text:
Writer Paul Benjamin is nearly hit by a bus when he leaves Auggie Wren‚Äôs smoke shop. Stranger Rashid Cole saves his life, and soon middle-aged Paul tells homeless Rashid that he wouldn‚Äôt mind a short-term housemate. Still grieving over his wife‚Äôs murder, Paul is moved by both Rashid‚Äôs quest to reconnect with his father and Auggie‚Äôs discovery that a woman who might be his daughter is about to give¬†birth.
I miss the good old times when dialogues and the way they were delivered made a movie. No cuts, no unnecessary editing, just one long take of William Hurt telling you a story that involves Sir Walter Raleigh, Queen Elizabeth, tobacco and the weight of smoke or a sequence with Harvey Keitel sharing one of his many life wisdoms amidst the heavy cigar smoke: 
'If it happens, it happens. If it doesn't, it doesn't. Do ya understand what I'm sayin'? Ya never know what's gonna happen next. And the moment you think you do, that's the moment you don't know a goddamn thing. This is what we call a paradox. Are you following me?'
Hell yes, I do. Laid back 90's Miramax anything-goes-ness. Written by Paul Auster. Tom Waits songs. Keitel. William Hurt whisper-talking. Stockard Channing in an eye patch. Smoking, talking. Dog Day, Spike Lee, This. New York on film beats the ever-living shit out of actually being in New York. One of my favorite endings of any film. A slow burn of interconnected stories, each layer unfurling like smoke in the air‚Äîintimate, bittersweet, and best savored without rushing. Just don‚Äôt expect a deep inhale.

Title: What Time Is It¬†There?
Text:

Title: Magnetic¬†Rose
Text:
‚ÄúMagnetic Rose‚Äù is about what happens when a deep space corporate freighter is called upon to investigate a distress signal from what ought to be a derelict space¬†station.
Our memories define us, but they also entrap us, they are a siren song disguised as a distress call set to the tune of Madama Butterfly designed to lure our identity-ship back into the past and smash it against the rocks of the long-forgotten space station wreckage of who we used to be. Don‚Äôt get lost in the holographic fantasy-realm of your own history just because there's a hot lady with a nice singing voice there, sometimes the past is just decaying space-junk that needs to be taken out with the rest of the space-trash. It's haunting and often terrifying, but it's also incredibly beautiful. Magnetic Rose is a must-see for every fan of anime, horror, and science-fiction. Day 4 of quarantine:

The aesthetics of garbage. The two most popular reviews here, as of now, both make reference to German‚Äôs Hard to be a God and while that seems an odd reference point for what is a serial killer procedural, it makes sense in both its emphasis on shared misery and in how experiential

Title: Woodstock
Text:
An intimate look at the Woodstock Music & Art Festival held in Bethel, NY in 1969, from preparation through cleanup, with historic access to insiders, blistering concert footage, and portraits of the concertgoers; negative and positive aspects are shown, from drug use by performers to naked fans sliding in the mud, from the collapse of the fences by the unexpected hordes to the surreal arrival of National Guard helicopters with food and medical assistance for the impromptu city of¬†500,000. √ó
‚ÄúWe must be in heaven, man.‚Äù
Michael Wadleigh‚Äôs 
Woodstock
 is a sprawling landmark concert-documentary that captures the spirit of the youth of the late '60s and the signalling of the end of that halcyon. Edited by both Martin Scorsese and Thelma Schoonmaker and partially shot by Scorsese himself, the documentary employed a cin√©ma v√©rit√© style that was reminiscent of other concert films of the time.
It was August 15, 1969. The Manson Family murders had occurred just a few days ago, the Stonewall riots the month before, and the assassinations of Martin Luther King Jr. and Bobby Kennedy the year earlier. All the while, America was still reeling from the effects of the Vietnam War. And in the midst of‚Ä¶ 
more Soul Sacrifice. As curious as I've been about this movie and its place in the culture, I was kind of dreading its four-hour runtime. I've never been that into concert films in general, either. But my husband loves this movie and wanted me to watch it with him, so I gritted my teeth and agreed. And it just mesmerized me. The time went by like nothing. The musical performances are electric, the sense of history is stunning, the access is fantastic, and you get to actually see the process of watching some organizers go from "We're selling $15 tickets to a few thousand people" to "I guess we're throwing a free be-in for the world's biggest commune." I maybe could do without‚Ä¶

Title: A Snake of¬†June
Text:
A woman is being stalked by a stranger. His stalking turns to blackmail when he sends her copies of photos of her in an embarrassing position. Now he controls her and she has to do anything he says.¬†Anything.
An surreal thrillfest exploring sexuality and erotic corruption, filtered through an incredibly wet and humid monochrome blue and evoking Lynch/Cronenberg mind bending of the highest order. Absolutely stunning and very much my kind of perfect Tsukamoto jam‚Äîblue. I still hold the hypothesis that Tsukamoto is following a thematic trend of animalistic dehumanization, this time exploring a perspective of self-destructive sexuality disrupting the ordinary and plain lives of a married couple. Following his stylized, black-and-white neo-noir bullet ballet featuring his directorial trademarks and a climactic bloodbath, we now enter a blue monochromatic surreal nightmare with thriller elements that shreds humanity into pieces of voyeurism, sexual impulses and the desire to live and stop suffering. Extramarital sexual desire is summarized in a form of self-humilliation. The result is a sense-assaulting psychological cataclysm which inner turmoil is metaphorically represented by the tumultuous rainy weather invading every frame. Even if one analyzes the storytelling structure, you can see the influence that‚Ä¶

Title: Old¬†Henry
Text:
A widowed farmer and his son warily take in a mysterious, injured man with a satchel of cash. When a posse of men claiming to be the law come for the money, the farmer must decide who to trust. Defending a siege of his homestead, the farmer reveals a talent for gun-slinging that surprises everyone calling his true identity into¬†question.
If you like Tim Blake Nelson talking in a laconic old tymey way and Stephen Dorff as a villain, then run, don't walk to see this! The kind of Western they just don't make anymore! It‚Äôs nice to watch a movie that‚Äôs not trying to melt my brain or give me a heart attack for a change. 
Old Henry
¬†is just telling a fine western story in the simplest way possible. With the help of its great cast, likable characters and beautiful dialogue, it manages to pull it off. OLD HENRY is my kind of western: a brutal slice of throwback genre entertainment told with unforgiving gravitas. Title: The¬†Queen
Text:
The Queen is an intimate behind the scenes glimpse at the interaction between HM Elizabeth II and Prime Minister Tony Blair during their struggle, following the death of Diana, to reach a compromise between what was a private tragedy for the Royal family and the public‚Äôs demand for an overt display of¬†mourning.
Manages to study, respect, and ridicule the royal family with satisfying wit. It‚Äôs an entirely cinematic portrayal of a recent event that expresses the distinction between outer and inner viewpoints, ultimately becoming more touching and comedically driven than you‚Äôd expect. 
Helen Mirren is THE reason The Queen works. With her pitch-perfect line delivery, she fully embodies Elizabeth II with subtle expression and magnanimous strength. She captures the tragedy of the situation, yet never forgets to reveal her humanity and delight that is often hidden from the public. It‚Äôs almost as if the queen watches and learns from her, THAT‚ÄôS how good she is. Title: Both Sides of the¬†Blade
Text:
Jean and Sara have been living together for 10 years. When they first met, Sara was living with Fran√ßois, Jean‚Äôs best friend and an admirer from back when he played rugby. Jean and Sara love each other. One day, Sara sees Fran√ßois in the street. He does not notice her, but she is overtaken by the sensation that her life could suddenly change. Fran√ßois gets back in touch with Jean. For the first time in years. He suggests they start working together again. From here on, things spiral out of¬†control. √ó
Being French is simply no way to live a life A white woman living in a post-colonial African country refuses to abandon her family‚Äôs coffee plantation even as civil war brews around her. A derelict spaceship full of criminals sails across the stars towards a black hole, adrift between their histories on Earth and the oblivion that awaits them in the cosmos. A former officer in the French Foreign Legion remembers his time stationed in Djibouti, where his men lost themselves in the desert (and each other) while preparing for a fight that never came.
The people in Claire Denis movies are seldom in a hurry, but they‚Äôre often out of time. They‚Äôre drawn and quartered between the soft flesh of memory and the acrid metal of waking life ‚Äî‚Ä¶ 
more Euphoria High but they are middle aged and French. Sorry. It somehow made me think of Trouble Every Day more than any of Denis more grounded movies. It pretty much is about how camera negotiates space between two tense bodies and Denis usual formal excellence, editing and camera, are great at it. Both Sides of the Blade also suggest Denis stab at making a more balanced Pialat movie. Some great work from Binoche and Lindon even more so because so much of it is about how their bodies are positioned inside the frame. Relationships are hard. The first great movie about how the Covid pandemic turned everybody into a volatile, horny maniac Torn between Vincent Lindon and Gr√©goire Colin is probably a woman's luckiest dilemma. In Both Sides of the Blade, Claire Denis' newest messy romantic drama, Juliette Binoche tries to balance her affections towards two men, and it backfires in the most explosive manner possible. 
Not Denis' career best by any stretch, this still reeks of her trademarks of sentimentality, feminine identity and black experience, which eventually counterbalance all the flaws. Despite a lukewarm first half of slow-burn buildup, the story picks up pace in the second, amping up emotions, tensions and dramatic scenes to repay the long wait. Lindon and Binoche are great enough veterans to pull off the equal parts sensual and turbulent dynamics with ease, while Colin still has the look and charms to disturb the couple's perfect existence. Despite an unsatisfying closure, Both Sides of the Blade still serves its purpose beautifully as an engrossing arthouse drama. Recommended. I was the only person at my screening with any colour in their hair BERLINALE FILM 4
Personally, this ranks below titane as it doesn‚Äôt have enough ass shots of Vincent lindon ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my Rue d‚ÄôAmsterdam wife.‚Äù
I would have liked flashbacks to explain Sara‚Äôs (Juliette Binoche) former relationship and why she was drawn to Fran√ßois (Gr√©goire Colin). Sara interviews people on the radio and it reminded me of the movie 
C‚Äômon C‚Äômon
. Scenes when Sara and Jean (Vincent London) were fighting seemed like C√©sar bait much in the same way that 
Revolutionary Road 
felt like Oscar bait. It also channeled 
Marriage Story 
but there was no wall-punching and the scenes were blocked better.¬†
Also watch for director Claire Denis‚Äô cameo in the party scene. Commuterland Paris, a casual domestic geography in familiar handheld, but the seasons are changing, skies are gray; everything is liminal, especially the world of sports, a zone in which established hierarchies of race and class become mutable (that‚Äôs why Denis stages a FaceTime call in which a member of France‚Äôs 1998 World Cup-winning squad explains Frantz Fanon).
Some of the funniest, harshest and most accurate domestic arguments ever‚Äîthe way Binoche leverages Lindon‚Äôs insecurity to turn offense into defense; the way the subject of the argument is invariably subsumed into a meta-argument about communication styles; ‚Äúeach sentence is a breath.‚Äù¬†
Need to sit with this one but it strikes me as one of Denis‚Äôs major films, a complex synthesis of familiar themes like female erotic abandon, postcolonialism, nostalgia and spiritual unrest, mixed families, and the up-to-the-minute tactility of French life (the way Marcus‚Äôs mask outlines his lips‚Ä¶). I never thought I‚Äôd see a Denis film that would elicit in me little more than a tired ‚Äúokay, boomer,‚Äù but here we are. Considering the world needs another film about tortured infidelity the way it needs another pandemic airborne illness, the film‚Äôs inherent uselessness can never quite save three moody, mercurial performances from feeling like they‚Äôre wasted on such tired material. One mid-film sequence stands out as the ghost of some more intense, special, strange film that might have been; Binoche struggling to balance the irrationality of her intensely corporeal responsiveness to even the sound of Colin‚Äôs voice with her very real emotional ties to Lindon, all of which Denis shoots like the stuff of some shadowy political thriller‚Ä¶

Title: Bullet¬†Ballet
Text:

Day 30/30
I did it.
I watched 
Bullet Ballet
, every day throughout April. Not sure if that speaks more about the film's quality or my autism, but in any case, this has been quite a ride. I don't necessarily recommend doing this sort of thing since it could potentially ruin your enjoyment of a film, but I guess due to my obsession with this one, the enjoyment stayed pretty consistent. On the other hand, I see that my challenge caught the attention of some people and made them interested to watch the film. That really means a lot to me because I think it deserves a lot more recognition.
With the challenge completed, let's break things down.
The movie is‚Ä¶ 
more another weird and sad b&w psychological nightmare from tsukamoto about pursuing meaning through mechanical and bodily destruction in a decaying, industrialized japan, yes, but the simplicity of the premise here (a practically farcical descent into the criminal underworld in search of a gun he can use to kill himself with) means that large sections of this play like a stranger, more unhinged, almost science-fiction version of that section of

It kicks ass to imagine the Tolkien estate soberly watching this in silence as they decide whether or not to allow Jackson to adapt Lord of the Rings for the big screen. Just a room full of 100 year old men shifting uncomfortably in their tweed as they watch the barf drinking scene. You can actually see Peter Jackson learning how to make a movie in real time, it's quite something. Peter Jackson's proving grounds take the shape of a hilarious, disgusting horror film that is extremely low budget, yet highly entertaining.
Much like with Raimi's Evil Dead, Jackson shows his raw, unpolished talents here. He is clearly someone who know how to do a lot with not very much. He has this vibrant creativity in all his films, whether good or bad. 
The premise of this film is wonderfully silly and it works to add to the light tone of the film. Title: The Forty-Year-Old¬†Version
Text:
Desperate for a breakthrough as she nears the big 4-0, struggling New York City playwright Radha finds inspiration by reinventing herself as a¬†rapper.
THE 40 YEAR OLD VERSION is a hysterical knockout of a crowd pleaser. Sharply written, beautifully acted & brilliantly directed in black and white, all by (remember this name) Radha Blank. This is the kind of discovery that makes the Sundance Film Festival so special. An absolute delight from beginning to end. The positives on this one:
‚Ä¢¬†It takes on some unusual cinematic topics, including the pettiest annoyances of reaching middle age, and the feeling of having not lived up to your early potential.
‚Ä¢¬†The premise, about a failed playwright who turns to rap to reinvent herself, is also unconventional.
‚Ä¢ It's damn funny, with sharp dialogue and sharp emotions.
‚Ä¢ The acting is terrific.
The negatives: 
‚Ä¢ The black-and-white photography is more muddy than artful.
‚Ä¢ The protagonist comes across as pretty narcissistic and self-absorbed. Yes, she's having a mid-life crisis, but that doesn't excuse the way she abuses her long-suffering, ridiculously loyal best friend, or blows off people when she doesn't need them, then gets offended if they treat her‚Ä¶ 
more ‚ÄúAnd maybe next time if it don't kill you, could you put some mayonnaise on both sides of this dry-ass bread?‚Äù
Ever since Radha Blank won the Directing Award in the U.S. Dramatic category at the Sundance Film Festival earlier this year, I was eager to see it.
The film is in black and white and shifts to color when she's envisioning the execution of the play she wrote. The film starts off documentary style: multiple people are interviewed about what it's like to turn forty. Then, enter the world of Radha (Radha Blank) whose seemingly autobiographical film has a similar vibe to Cheryl Dunye's 
The Watermelon Woman
. Both women have fresh and unapologetic voices, but are uniquely their own‚Ä¶
