Title: Station¬†Eleven
Text:
The survivors of a devastating flu attempt to rebuild and reimagine the world anew ‚Äì while holding on to the best of what‚Äôs been¬†lost.
I loved this. But also, I would rather die in a pandemic than spend the post-apocalypse with theater kids. There was something refreshing about Station Eleven. 
It‚Äôs 10 hours blissfully free of sarcasm, snark and cleverness. There is no Ryan Reynolds or Will Ferrell. No Superheroes. No over-processed CGI, car chases, or endless streams of gun fire. 
There is drama and death, but it‚Äôs never exploitive. There are no good guys and bad guys, just people trying to stay alive and make connections. 
There is love, loss, and loneliness, but not in ways you expect. It doesn‚Äôt define anyone. People overcome.
There was no attempt to sell me anything. 
I doubt there will be a season 2. 
Arts are respected.
I loved it. ‚ÄúWhat message did you leave?‚Äù
‚ÄúThat I‚Äôd be home soon.‚Äù
Lovely, devastating stuff.

But I like this story and love the graphic novel, so seeing it adapted for the screen is always fun for me, even if it almost always loses something in the process (which is why the best adaptation is still the Motion Comic, which is basically just the pages from the graphic novel animated). I really wonder what inspired this film considering it lacks any creativity whatsoever

Title: High Flying¬†Bird

Stephen Soderbergh shot this movie on an iPhone.
I couldn‚Äôt even write this Letterboxd entry on mine without numerous typos.
Really puts things in perspective for me, thanks Steven. Steven Soderbergh loves making heist movies. That was obvious from the ‚ÄúOcean‚Äôs Eleven‚Äù trilogy, and the more recent ‚ÄúLogan Lucky;‚Äù in less explicit ways, it‚Äôs also evident in many of his other films. And while it‚Äôs likely that Soderbergh has a soft spot for thieves, it‚Äôs more accurate to say that he‚Äôs drawn to stories about people who try to steal back a measure of self-worth.
‚ÄúErin Brockovich‚Äù has the trappings of a legal drama, but it builds to a final scene in which its heroine scores a personal supply of restorative justice from the pockets of a corrupt system. ‚ÄúThe Informant!‚Äù is an off-kilter comedy about a whistleblower who embezzled millions from his own company while snitching on his‚Ä¶ 
more I'm not a sports fan and not interested in the politics of the sports industry so I was never 100% engaged but very cool that Soderbergh is continuing to experiment with the iPhone. Title: Cliffhanger
Text:
A year after losing his friend in a tragic 4,000-foot fall, former ranger Gabe Walker and his partner, Hal, are called to return to the same peak to rescue a group of stranded climbers, only to learn the climbers are actually thieving hijackers who are looking for boxes full of¬†money.
Endlessly, beautifully committed to loud, nasty violence, never missing a chance to beat the hell out of its hero and leave a bloody mess of his enemies. Lithgow makes a terrific villain, totally having a blast matching Sly's every punch with a terrible quip. Bench-pressing a guy onto a stalactite has to be one of the all-time great action movie kills. No contrivance is omitted in its pursuit of cheap thrills. And then there's the fantastic late-analog spectacle. Literally every trick in the book is deployed here, from (outstanding) matte-paintings to miniatures to rear-screen to good old fashioned practical stunts. It's Bond level, really a superb technical achievement. The plane-to-plane transfer sequence is worth it alone (and essentially remained unequaled until THE DARK KNIGHT RISES). Harlin's best movie in a walk.
Edit: Can't believe I forgot to mention Rex Linn's constant, literally frothing-at-the-mouth apoplectic rage. The opening scene of this movie vividly renders one of my greatest nightmares...dating someone who's into outdoorsy stuff like hiking, mountain biking, climbing, etc.
Solid. Good action. Great locations. Rooker, Stallone, Lithgow, Leon and Sides God Rex Linn. Free Solo
 meets Four Loko in this 90s Stallone action classic (which feels more like a product of the 80s than it does the 90s) where sad boi Sly mopes around a snowy mountaintop before getting tangled up with murderous psychopath John Lithgow and a criminal crew that somehow actually feels representative of realistic coworker interaction in how much they just can‚Äôt fucking stand each other. Sure, it‚Äôs a total 
Die Hard
 rip-off, but it‚Äôs got giant explosions, bloody kills (shoulder pressing a dude into a stalactite is ‚Äúfuck yeah‚Äù incarnate), gorgeous mountain matte painting backdrops, and enough extreme climbing stunts to give cliffheads (is that a term? Idk) a full body orgasm. Plus, it features the sickest mid-air heist ever filmed by a guy not named Chris ‚ÄúTop Dawg‚Äù Nolan. As long as you can make it past the low key super traumatizing opening scene, it‚Äôs one boss ass time.

Title: Symbiopsychotaxiplasm: Take¬†One

Title: Scenes from a¬†Marriage
Text:
Johan and Marianne are married and seem to have it all. Their happiness, however, is a fa√ßade for a troubled relationship, which becomes even rockier when Johan admits that he‚Äôs having an affair. Before long, the spouses separate and move towards finalizing their divorce, but they make attempts at reconciling. [theatrical version] 
Damn. Really wish I caught the 5 hour version first because I would have loved to sit and endure each and every detail of this relationship. Very rare for me to think something like that after spending nearly 3 hours with a movie that is entirely conversations, but Bergman's way of capturing the pain in these characters was too real to not feel completely immersed. Marriage Story is 
sad
. It's an emotional journey where I'm in the room crying and walking away with a new found appreciation for my fiance and love overall.
Scenes from a Marriage is 
depressing
. I didn't cry and I didn't emotionally connect with the two characters. I just walked away from the film depressed with no hope on love ever lasting. After the three hour movie; I turned it off, jumped in my car, and went to get ice cream to cheer myself up.

Title: Winter¬†Sleep
Text:
Aydƒ±n is a hotel owner and a retired actor in rural Turkey. As winter emerges he begins navigating the conflicts within the relationships with his wife, sister and¬†existence.
Aydin is a deeply flawed human being. He is condescending, manipulative, phony, he thinks of himself as profound when in fact he is shallow. He mistakes his selfishness for altruism, he expects nothing in return but ardently seeks personal gain or comfort. He finds his encounters with the tenants embarrassing, he avoids them like the plague, yet he doesn't miss a chance to mockingly assert his superiority. He wants to appear modest yet he will accept any words of praise or will turn others' shame into his moment of glory. He is friendly to the tourists not because he is kind but because it gives him a sense of gratification. He writes for the local newspaper to satisfy his intellectual‚Ä¶

I took the train from Paris to Milan a long time ago and I remember looking out the window at the majestic mountains admiring them, of course, but it wasn't until we got into Northern Italy that I found them beautiful and alive. It was there that real life was sprinkled throughout the mountains, with clotheslines everywhere and junkyards and swing sets. It was there that I loved those mountains.
Give Nuri Bilge Ceylan the most beautiful setting in the world and he will show you the clotheslines. It is why I trust him. I will listen to anything he wants to tell me because I know that whatever story he tells, it will‚Ä¶

He is educated, cultured, inviting, and well-spoken, and, most importantly, he is reasonable. Title: In the Mouth of¬†Madness

Title: Life
Text:
Two men in 1930s Mississippi become friends after being sentenced to life in prison together for a crime they did not¬†commit.
A lot of people put this film down because they see Eddie Murphy and Martin Lawrence and automatically assume it's a comedy. It's not a comedy. It has a lot of funny moments, but it's really a depressing, heartfelt, and bittersweet drama that boasts surprisingly fantastic performances from it's leads. Eddie Murphy has'nt been this great since 48 Hrs and is even better. Martin Lawrence has'nt been this great since, well, ever but manages to be amazing. The make up is very convincing. The drama is as strong as the comedy, which is hilarious. Sure, there are times this tries a little too hard to be the next Shawshank Redemption, but this is still well acted, entertaining, and highly underrated. This deserves more praise and attention than it's been given over the years. The main negative criticism I‚Äôve seen leveled at this movie is that it‚Äôs either too sad to be a comedy or too funny to be a drama, as if the movie isn‚Äôt literally called LIFE. Haven't seen this banger since back when it was in constant rotation on TBS in the mid 2000s. During the channel's commercial breaks, the advertisement for when it was going to be playing on TBS always contained the cornbread scene when Eddie and Martin first arrive in jail. That scene has been burned into my brain ever since I could remember. 
Life
 is a great movie, it's got an absolutely fire cast, it's goddamn hysterical and it's surprisingly emotional as well. Murphy and Lawrence play off of each other so well, it's a shame that they didn't do more things together other than this and 
Boomerang
. Definitely add it to your watchlist, I guarantee that you'll get a kick out of it.

Title: Pee-wee as¬†Himself
Text:

Beautiful and dreamy. I‚Äôll miss him forever. I really don‚Äôt know what to say. It‚Äôs hard watching artistic heroes die and this somehow‚Ä¶idk. Helped the grief move through me a bit more? Title: The Right¬†Stuff
Text:
As the Space Race ensues, seven pilots set off on a path to become the first American astronauts to enter space. However, the road to making history brings forth momentous¬†challenges.

and golly gee whiz did it inspire INTERSTELLAR. it also inspired this entry to be so uninteresting, because i watched the film for a piece related to Interstellar, which is the film that has completely sapped my critical faculties dry this weekend. ‚ÄúThere was a demon who lived in the air‚Ä¶‚Äù
Director Phillip Kauffman‚Äôs love letter to the Mercury Space Program is really a love letter to a certain ephemeral essence. It can easily be dismissed as a love letter to American exceptionalism, provided you overlook its constant, subtle and not so subtle reminders that even in its finest hour, America had - and has - a long, long way to go. 
The Right Stuff
 loves America deeply without ever losing perspective.
It‚Äôs influence can be found everywhere and it ranks high on my list of films that shouldn‚Äôt exist yet somehow do. 73/100
Begins and ends weakly: the Yeager prologue strains too hard to be iconic (and is rife with tin-eared dialogue, unlike the rest of the movie‚Äî"We did it! We finally broke the sound barrier" someone cries, as if anyone in earshot or in the audience hadn't worked that out‚Äîwhile the epilogue ("And for a brief moment, Gordo Cooper became the greatest pilot anyone had ever seen") just feels like a cheap shot...especially given that it's spoken by Levon Helm, who also plays Yeager's gum-loaning wingman. But the arrival of Jeff Goldblum and Harry Shearer in minor roles heralds a marvelous change of pace, and Kaufman's affectionate satire of the Mercury program's training regimen and PR campaign enlivens docudrama conventions by‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Blob
Text:
In Arborville, California, three high school students try to protect their hometown from a gelatinous alien life form that engulfs everything it¬†touches.
The blob kills a date rapist and someone talking during a movie. This is the most satisfying movie of all time. I love the way this movie sets up a number of characters like the HS football player, the stern but kindly sheriff and the waitress he asks on a date, who you think are going to be major characters, with their little character beats and romantic aspirations only to do a brutal rug pull, nope sorry they once had hopes, dreams and personalities, but they're blob goo now. I really loved this film back in the day. So much so that I wrote a letter to Fangoria and to my surprise... they published it! A few months later, I received a signed copy of the screenplay by "Partners in Slime" Frank Darbont and Chuck Russell. I still have it. I think Darabont sent it himself. 
So revisiting the film... perhaps it doesn't reach the heights of The Thing or The Fly but still one of the best of the 80's remakes of 50's horror classics. Still adore the bazooka to the manhole escape scene. 
Extras on this Collector's Edition Blu-ray are insane.

Title: High Plains¬†Drifter
Text:
A gunfighting stranger comes to the small settlement of Lago. After gunning down three gunmen who tried to kill him, the townsfolk decide to hire the Stranger to hold off three outlaws who are on their¬†way.
Jesus, Clint, this is some dark shit With High Plains Drifter, Clint Eastwood created arguably the most debatable and ambiguous film of his entire career - both as an actor and as a director. There is so much about this eerie western that doesn't get answered. So many details missing. So many presumptions to be made. 
Most revisionist westerns of its time were busying themselves rewriting the West as it had been told by Hollywood, mostly wrongly, for over 40 years. Eastwood decided to take the traditional mainstream western, slap it around a while and show that something could still be done with it - just as long as it was willing to change.
It's well known by now that Eastwood's mysterious stranger rides into a town‚Ä¶ 
more Eastwood channels two of his biggest collaborators (Leone and Siegel) into one of the grimmest westerns I've seen, that plays sorta like if the wandering Ronin in a Kurosawa movie was actually a rapist monster as well as a brutal killer and the local pacifist townspeople who hire him to protect them from murderous outlaws turn out to be just as corrupt and contemptible as he is. We're already living in hell so might as well stop pretending.

Title: Up
Text:
Carl Fredricksen spent his entire life dreaming of exploring the globe and experiencing life to its fullest. But at age 78, life seems to have passed him by, until a twist of fate (and a persistent 8-year old Wilderness Explorer named Russell) gives him a new lease on¬†life.
My family went to see 
Up 
on my grandpa‚Äôs 70th birthday back in 2009. When the movie was over, I remember everyone being ecstatic - and undeniably moved. At age 9, I think it was probably the first time I‚Äôd seen my parents shed tears in a movie. My dad immediately dubbed the first 15 minutes of the film ‚ÄúThe Robot Test‚Äù - because 
‚Äúif you don‚Äôt cry in the first 15 minutes, you‚Äôre a robot.‚Äù
My grandpa, Jim, loved 
Up
 more than anyone else. As soon as he‚Äôd seen it once, he wanted to see it again. Happy to do so, we all went back to the theater for the second time that day. A few weeks later, my‚Ä¶ 
more One hundred years from now, film scholars will study the 15 wordless minutes near the beginning of this movie as one of the finest examples of storytelling across any medium or genre. I say this without threat of hyperbole. Dad what's wrong? 
Grown up stuff, sweetheart. 
Like what? 
Daddy's just a bit afraid for the world.
Is it because of the Orange Hamster Man? 
Yep.
Are you sad? 
A bit. 
Wanna watch a movie? 
Yeah. 
Which one? 
You pick. 
My kids know me so well.

Title: Picnic
Text:
Believing that the world will end that very day, three mental patients Coco, Tsumuji, and Satoru set out upon a journey. Walking upon the tops of the walls of the city, they seek to find a picnic spot with the best vantage point to view the final¬†event.
when your circle's small but y'all crazy i prefer hell.
heaven would be so boring.
picnic
 is ethereal, heavy, and strongly symbolic with a
deep meaning. albeit i wish it was longer because it left
me wanting more. it made me feel as if i was watching
a dark, beautiful poem. the cinematography is immensely
stunning. i got deeply absorbed in the dreamlike picture -
especially in the final scene, i felt overwhelmingly sad. Anxiety and apathy are inflamed at a mental asylum. Darkness and demons from the not-so-distant past torment and take their toll on these troubled people. Tired of being walled-off from the outside world, they decide to take matters into their own hands. After fleeing the mental asylum, they leap from ledge to ledge - learning more about their surroundings and themselves in the process. During their exploration outside the asylum, they begin to believe that the earth will soon be annihilated. So, why not have a picnic and enjoy it?
Horrifying and hypnotic; 
Picnic
 does not shy away from portraying the perturbed, but the quirky characters and sometimes staggeringly good cinematography make it a little easier to bear. I found‚Ä¶ 
more

Title: The¬†Town
Text:
Doug MacRay is a longtime thief, who, smarter than the rest of his crew, is looking for his chance to exit the game. When a bank job leads to the group kidnapping an attractive branch manager, he takes on the role of monitoring her ‚Äì but their burgeoning relationship threatens to unveil the identities of Doug and his crew to the FBI Agent who is on their¬†case.
The Town
 feels as if Ben Affleck watched the opening scene from 
The Dark Knight
 and asked himself "Would this work as a two hour movie?"
Yes. Yes it does. The entire scene wherein Ben Affleck, Jeremy Renner, and the rest of the gang are dressed like a nun while robbing a bank is more spooky than 'The Nun' (2018) itself. This feels like the type of movie that would play on FX at like 2 pm on a Friday or something.

Title: Knock Down the¬†House
Text:
In 2018, a young bartender in the Bronx, a coal miner‚Äôs daughter in West Virginia, a grieving mother in Nevada and a registered nurse in Missouri join a movement of insurgent candidates challenging powerful incumbents in Congress. Without political experience or corporate money, these four women are attempting to do what many consider¬†impossible.
it's so wild to watch a documentary about politics and actually feel better afterwards Redacted "This all belongs to us." A genuinely exciting and inspiring time for grassroots American politics.

Title: The¬†Alpinist
Text:
Marc-Andr√© Leclerc, an exceptional climber, has made solo his religion and ice his homeland. When filmmaker Peter Mortimer begins his film, he places his camera at the base of a British Columbia cliff and waits patiently for the star climber to come down to answer his questions. Marc Andr√©, a little uncomfortable, prefers to return to the depths of the forest where he lives in a tent with his girlfriend Brette Harrington. In the heart of winter, Peter films vertiginous solos on fragile ice. He tries to make appointments with the climber who is never there and does not seem really concerned by this camera pointed at him ‚ÄúFor me, it would not be a solo if there was someone else‚Äù . Marc-Andr√© is thus, the ‚Äúpure light‚Äù of the mountaineers of his time, which marvel Barry Blanchard, Alex Honnold or Reinhold Messner, interviewed in the film. An event film for an extraordinary¬†character. √ó
marc-andr√© leclerc is a fascinating documentary subject and an incredibly inspiring person. this documentary doesn‚Äôt deserve him.
mixed feelings because i do think it does a decent job at showing leclerc in an authentic light that really gets across how inspiring of a person he is. but to give the film credit for that seems like a stretch, hard to shoot a smile like that and see him in a bad light.
i think leclerc and his accomplishments are nothing short of astounding, and it‚Äôs the only reason this film is even a little bit likable. i think the best way to see how awful the filmmakers handle this story is to see just how well elizabeth chai vasarhelyi and‚Ä¶ 
more didn‚Äôt have ‚Äúcry at a climbing documentary‚Äù on today‚Äôs bingo card but here we are extremely jealous of any person that can live their life to the fullest without needing any validation from the outside world. super inspiring

Title: Comrades, Almost a Love¬†Story
Text:
Jun arrives in Hong Kong from mainland China, hoping to be able to earn enough money to marry his girlfriend back home. He meets the streetwise Qiao and they become friends. As friendship turns into love, problems develop, and although they seem meant for each other they somehow keep missing¬†out.
Love in the materialistic city. The right person at perhaps the wrong time, but time keeps moving and so too they until one day both become right. Until then the pain in wanting something so close but not quite ready is almost cruel, visions of the ideal so fully-formed in its proximity to the now it seems just within reach with a bit more work but the 80-20 rule rears its head and that last 20 just seems to never quite come. It can with time. Until then there is still a life to live before they can become part of yours.
Just really nice, and a rare example of friendship naturally transforming into romance on film. Certainly there have been movies which attempt to‚Ä¶ 
more i mean, what's not to love? Maggie Cheung... Christopher Doyle as a horny English teacher!? 
relentlessly melodramatic romance that touches upon the chinese diaspora and the frustrated upward mobility of mainlanders vs. their hong kong counterparts and also touches about MAGGIE CHEUNG. i mean... the best. Leon Lai is, comparatively, a chore and a half. wasn't expecting this to go where it went (geographically, at least), but the tinny synth vibes pay off, and the romance is believable (and oddly relatable) even when it isn't. 
i don't even want to see the restoration. hilariously flubbed subtitles and the soft haze of VHS brings this to life.

Title: Paddleton
Text:
An unlikely friendship between two neighbors becomes an unexpectedly emotional journey when the younger man is diagnosed with terminal¬†cancer.
Easily a top 5 in terms of saddest movies I‚Äôve seen. Nothing like a good cry on a Saturday night. Mark Duplass and Ray Romano both give some GREAT performances in this that I already know will be insanely overlooked. ¬†There were moments that felt so real and others that feel a little clich√© and I would‚Äôve liked some more consistency but damn. The end (
the scene
) is one of the most heartbreakingly realistic things I‚Äôve ever seen in film.¬†Props to the performances and direction because it was truly unlike anything I‚Äôve seen before. This was much better than I expected. This is great. 
This is sweat.
This is touching.
This is heartwarming. 
This is sad. 
This is fun. 
This is a beautiful friendship. ‚ÄúYou always look sad when we finish.‚Äù
I‚Äôm in love with this. I could‚Äôve watched these guys hang out for so much longer, and I think that‚Äôs the point. Their time together isn‚Äôt particularly planned out or even all that eventful ‚Äî no one moment feels so unique, but within each rambling conversation, you could just stay inside the warmth of it forever. Easily one of my favorite movies about friendship and an incredibly realistic depiction of love between men. Duplass and Romano are both effortlessly charming, the script allowing for Romano to be utterly commanding.¬†
If I ever want to drown in my feelings, I could do a double feature of this and 
Old Joy
.

Title: The Imaginarium of Doctor¬†Parnassus
Text:
After a carnival troupe saves his life, a man agrees to help its immortal leader collect five souls and win a bet with the¬†devil.
I didn‚Äôt enjoy Terry Gilliam‚Äôs The Imaginarium of Dr. Parnassus all that much, but damn it, I respect it a great deal. First, the star of the film, Heath Ledger, died tragically of a prescription drug overdose in the middle of the production. Second, at the end of principal photography, that which included three of Ledger‚Äôs friends substituting for him to complete his role, Producer William Vince succumbed to cancer. Finally, during post production, Gilliam himself was hit by a car. It‚Äôs a testament to his tenacity that he just wouldn‚Äôt let go, that he just wouldn‚Äôt give up on the movie.
I adored many things about the film; the sumptuous visual spectacle, the classic ‚Äòdeal with the devil‚Äô conceit,‚Ä¶

Title: Never Rarely Sometimes¬†Always
Text:
A pair of teenage girls in rural Pennsylvania travel to New York City to seek out medical help after an unintended¬†pregnancy.
‚Äúwhat‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù
‚Äúgirl problems‚Äù
so special. it‚Äôs sparse in just the way it needs to be, the silence carrying us along with it. quiet despair is just the routine for so many, and this shows it with so much empathy that it made my heart ache. ugh An honest-to-god horror movie. The camera swings and lingers with all the tension of a Blumhouse movie and the care of a French romance. I went ‚Äúno no no no‚Äù every time a man was on the screen. Girls are made to grow up so fast. I was a grown-ass adult man in an office at the age of 23 scared to drive my big boy car¬†to a local doctor on my insurance and figure out why I kept passing out at the office and here are these two baby girls born after the towers fell putting their lives in repeated danger for a peace of mind they should‚Äôve always been afforded. Hell hell hell. Eliza Hittman has an attention to detail that, as proven here, can carry an entire film without words. Not just in the faces but in footsteps, blinks, and obviously hands. Even the smallest of actions speak so loudly. When something otherwise ‚Äúnormal‚Äù means something, you feel that difference. 
There‚Äôs a specific shot near the beginning when Autumn is laying in the bed after her ultrasound exam. The camera follows her face as she turns to her side, facing away from the monitor. In the midst of a situation that‚Äôs left her no room to breath, she finds solace where she can, in that moment it‚Äôs on the other side of that bed. That solace redefines itself throughout the film, but proves itself present in every moment, even if that moment is in the middle of a shitty NYC train station.

Title: The House with Laughing¬†Windows
Text:
A young restorer is commissioned to save a fresco representing the suffering of St. Sebastiano, which was painted on the wall of a local church by a mysterious, long-dead¬†artist.
Opting for the rural backdrop rather than cosmopolitan, 
The House with Laughing Windows
 lives deliciously within confines of the folk horror milieu, lacking the well documented motifs so commonly attributed to the giallo in favor of menacingly unstoppable atmosfear.
Establishing an eeriness from the get go with a disturbing opening (among the genre‚Äôs best) before throwing us into the fray with morbid paintings, deranged townsfolk and the local diabolical underbelly, the sinister looking (laughing) windows, and a seething/unforgettable final twist of pure bedlam.¬†A full fledged genre masterpiece with great performances and tight¬†direction that shouldn‚Äôt be slept on‚Äîbut in some weird way I think 
The House with Laughing Windows

Giallo
What a return to my newfound favorite genre. 
The House of the Laughing Windows
 is my favorite kind of giallo: a slow-burn psychological mindcreeper set in an isolated village that is real but also the manifestation of your mind. The definiton of that kind of giallo? It hooks its talons into your forehead and rips and rips until your mind itself comes apart. Delectable. 
The patiently dripping terror is palpable in how the film goes about its plot of mystery. All the killings happen off-screen, but the killer is as real and human as the inhabitants of the village. This giallo is no police procedural at all; there is no police, only the village-dwellers who are all potentially crazy‚Ä¶

Title: Burden of¬†Dreams
Text:
The Amazon rain forest, 1979. The crew of Fitzcarraldo (1982), a film directed by German director Werner Herzog, soon finds itself with problems related to casting, tribal struggles and accidents, among many other setbacks; but nothing compared to dragging a huge steamboat up a mountain, while Herzog embraces the path of a certain madness to make his vision come¬†true.
"If I abandon this project I would be a man without dreams, and I don't want to live like that."
Someone really missed out on a great opportunity to call this 
Herzcarraldo
. It's amazing how closely the making of Herzog's 
Fitzcarraldo
 parallels the actual story within the film itself. The film hit every possible snag in its production, from sets falling apart to cast and crew being attacked by natives. And while this is due in large part to Herzog's insane dedication to verisimilitude, it also needs to be said that the director never asks anyone to do anything he doesn't do himself. The problem is that there's almost nothing Herzog won't do himself. There's a shot in the documentary‚Ä¶ 
more "I'm tired of it all and I couldn't care less if they move the stupid ship ‚Äì or finish the fucking film."
 - Les Blank's personal production journal from 
Burden of Dreams
.
Les Blank is not a megalomaniac, and so he ends up making the same film Herzog is making, thematic beat for thematic beat, except without the self-important fabrications of make-believe and strained pretense. 
Herzog makes his film through force of will. Blank makes his through observational intimacy. When I was young I wanted to be Herzog. Now that I am old, I want to be Blank.
Best DVD-extra ever. Feeling a bit melancholy that auteur megalomania of this scale has gone so out of fashion in recent years. Like him or not, I√±√°rritu is the only guy keeping it alive.

So many wonderful hats ‚Ä¶ and such marvelous dancing. Surely they worked up quite an appetite. On December 31, 2019, not only the last day of the year but also the decade, I visited Fred Astaire‚Äôs grave in Chatsworth in the San Fernando Valley, where he had his ranch and where he spent some of the happiest times of his life. It was an extremely emotional experience for me, not only because I was finally able to stand at his resting place, but because I always knew that the event would mark the end of an era in my personal history‚Äîas well as the beginning of a new one.

Title: An Unmarried¬†Woman
Text:
A wealthy woman from Manhattan‚Äôs Upper East Side struggles to deal with her new identity and her sexuality after her husband of 16 years leaves her for a younger¬†woman.
Do you ever have the feeling where a movie was actually made for you? Where every character reminds you of either yourself or someone you know well? Where every time you hear the (perfect) score you feel energized and happy? Where every scene is so entertaining but also memorable and smart? Where the time period in which the movie takes place is the time you wish you could time travel back to? Where you know the location of the movie so well that you feel like you're there? Where the long takes are so good that you feel embraced with the characters? Where the dialogue is so natural and you feel as if you've said or could say lines that these characters say? Where you are comfortable with yet completely blown away by every scene? Yeah, that's what 
An Unmarried Woman
 is for me. I can't believe a man wrote this. There‚Äôs a great use of long takes AND Jill Clayburgh giving an outstanding performance AND feminist themes AND a combination of multiple amazing genres AND it‚Äôs from the 70s AND it takes place in New York AND it‚Äôs perfectly written AND I love the music AND there‚Äôs a great child performance AND I laughed several times AND I want to meet Erica AND every character is so damn relatable and realistic. If you live in NYC and you haven‚Äôt seen this, you have some work to do.

Title: Planes
Text:
Dusty is a cropdusting plane who dreams of competing in a famous aerial race. The problem? He is hopelessly afraid of heights. With the support of his mentor Skipper and a host of new friends, Dusty sets off to make his dreams come¬†true.
If there are World War II planes in this film does that mean there was a Plane Hitler? Pure cinema. Do not pay attention to any of the film's critics. They're all wrong.
 
Planes
 is simply put, the highest form of kin√©matographic art the world has thus seen. 
An epic cinematic odyssey full of gravitas and emotional weight, these ninety-one minutes have some of the most beautiful, solemn, thoughtful, poetic and hypnotic images you will ever see. 
The film is living photography. It is
 the film. To call the plot a major part of 
Planes
 would be a mistake, 
it is simply a vehicle for the visuals.
Kinesthetic excellence. Let go of preconcieved notions of what cinema must be and allow yourself to be enveloped in the world this genius auteur Klay Hall has constructed. Simulacra, postmodernism, post semiotics. Adieu au langage. The most important lesson from seeing Planes? It's okay to lie to your children.
Despite the target audience of the Cars franchise being boys, my daughter absolutely loves the films. She has every single diecast car toy, multiple race tracks, everything. Therefore, Planes has been a highly anticipated event for the wee one in my household for quite some time now, and in her world, today totally delivered. Title: Frantz
Text:
In the aftermath of WWI, a young German who grieves the death of her fianc√© in France meets a mysterious French man who visits the fiance‚Äôs grave to lay¬†flowers.
My assumption that Adrien and Frantz were lovers in France was a much better storyline than this ended up being Visually gorgeous. So many literary surprises. The emotions are delicate and powerful. There did come a point where I was ready for it to move on, though, rather than lingering eternally in the aching void of longing and uncertainty. The use of color to indicate emotion in an otherwise black-and-white film is so on the nose, and yet it's also so effective. -"You like this painting too?"
- "Yes, It makes me want to live."
I finally found a film by Fran√ßois Ozon that resonated with me, a film that touched me deeply, a film that I found romantic. My prejudices against him were buried along with 
Frantz
. If I were to describe 
Frantz
 in one word, it would be "delicate." More films should emerge that portray people, their psyches, their vulnerabilities, and their dilemmas with such tenderness and care. The new generation of cinema should be filled not only with more gore, sex, or excess, but also with films filled with such emotion.

Title: Judgment at¬†Nuremberg
Text:
In 1947, four German judges who served on the bench during the Nazi regime face a military tribunal to answer charges of crimes against humanity. Chief Justice Haywood hears evidence and testimony not only from lead defendant Ernst Janning and his defense attorney Hans Rolfe, but also from the widow of a Nazi general, an idealistic U.S. Army captain and reluctant witness Irene¬†Wallner.
sometimes you just wanna watch some actors thunder away With Judgment at Nuremberg director Stanley Kramer doesn't shy away from tackling a difficult and controversial subject that to many others would seem impossible to justly address, he isn't afraid of asking the important questions or delving into the intricate, grey areas that seem to have no way out. His view remains simple, clear and unabated but at the same time encloses the many different nuances and variables at play, without diluting and overshadowing its fundamental principles.
Based on the Judges' Trials that took place in Nuremberg in 1947 right after World War II as part of a series of military tribunals against followers of the Nazi regime, Abby Mann's screenplay is a magnificent showcase of the power and importance‚Ä¶ 
more The most important film I had never even heard of before.
"There was a fever over the land. A fever of disgrace, of indignity, of hunger. We had a democracy, yes, but it was torn by elements within. Above all, there was fear. Fear of today, fear of tomorrow, fear of our neighbors, and fear of ourselves."
While the question at the core of this three-hour historical courtroom epic is what blame could be placed on four German judges for the atrocities of the Nazi regime ... it also paints a much broader picture of this critical period in world history. Title: Mephisto
Text:
A German stage actor finds unexpected success and mixed blessings in the popularity of his performance in a Faustian play as the Nazis take power in pre-WWII Germany. As his associates and friends flee or are ground under by the Nazi terror, the popularity of his character supercedes his own existence until he finds that his best performance is keeping up appearances for his Nazi¬†patrons.
Based on Klaus Mann's novel 
Mephisto
, a semi-biography of the influential theater director and actor Gustaf Gr√ºndgens, and therefore banned in Germany for 20 years, Istv√°n Szab√≥'s second attack to the spreading terror of the National Socialist German Workers' Party earned him the attention of the Academy for the second time and winning for the first time. A masterpiece of art direction and allegorical irony, 
Mephisto
 is a full-scaled and highly ambitious artwork that revives the times of the pre-WWII Germany and Europe with a tremendous cinematic artistry bringing along one of the greatest movie performances of the 20th Century by Klaus Maria Brandauer as the theater puppet Hendrik H√∂fgen.
The opening of the film is the artistic statement: theater.‚Ä¶ 
more One of the most terrifying movies ever made about one's own devotion to their craft, and ultimately the point to which it consumes your own soul at the expense of those around you. But as far as adaptations of 
Faust
 can go, this is one among the most creative - especially when you are coming to consider the setting amidst Nazi Germany.
An old favourite from high school; but years later it still holds up beautifully. Fingers crossed more people come to see this. (Roger Ebert's Great Movies)
(Foreign language film)

Mephisto was a film that caught my attention based on how striking its movie poster was on Roger Ebert's Great Movies list, with this eerie-looking figure painted in white next to a swastika. The story follows a German stage actor named Hendrik during the period when the Nazi regime was beginning to take control of the country. The Nazi politicians love his role as Mephisto, which is essentially the devil character in a version of the Faust story. Title: The¬†Outsider
Text:
When an insidious supernatural force edges its way into a seemingly straightforward investigation into the gruesome murder of a young boy, it leads a seasoned cop and an unorthodox investigator to question everything they believe¬†in.
Inside every ten-episode miniseries is a two-hour movie struggling to get out. Sets up a very compelling, disorienting mystery with a really impressive, portentous mood in the first few episodes that it then kinda struggles to justify for the remaining like... seven hours. This is a fascinating and irresistible concoction. Its tone is a mix of Stephen King's uneasy acceptance of the supernatural coupled with the harsh look at the American justice system that Richard Price loves to bring to his work (see: The Wire, The Night Of).
Combine that with an exceptional cast firing on all cylinders and you have an engrossing 10-hour procedural that asks what would happen if our notion of reality was disrupted beyond what we can typically accept. 
But...
That finale did not quite stick the landing for me. Between the mindless action theatrics, some really confusing moments ("Who's Terry?") and that maddening final shot, I thought it was only somewhat satisfying. 
Still, up until that last bit, it's aces.

Title: Mr.¬†Klein
Text:
Paris, France, 1942, during the Nazi occupation. Robert Klein, a successful art dealer who benefits from the misfortunes of those who are ruthlessly persecuted, discovers by chance that there is another Robert Klein, apparently a Jewish man; someone with whom he could be mistakenly identified, something dangerous in such harsh¬†times.
Losey's best film and one of the most horrifying movies I have ever seen, the greatest film about fascism. "Tell me, the Kleins‚Äîare they French-French, or are there Jews in your family?"
Without question the oblique thriller 
Mr. Klein
 (
Monsieur Klein
) is the most compelling of the three Joseph Losey films I've now managed to see‚Äîthe others being the Harold Pinter collaborations 
Accident
 and 
The Go-Between
. In fact I'll grab the lowest-hanging fruit around and concur with the chorus who have deemed it potently Kafkaesque.
Set in 1942 Nazi-occupied Vichy France, Franco Solinas' screenplay revolves around Robert Klein (Alain Delon), a disreputable Parisian art dealer who buys paintings at pennies on the dollar from Jewish collectors desperately seeking their escape. Turnabout ensues when Klein finds himself the addressed recipient of a local Jewish newspaper, though he initially assumes the‚Ä¶ 
more In occupied Paris in 1942, a refined art dealer of Alsatian birth and Catholic religion takes advantage of the racial laws to do golden business with Jews, forced to sell off their property to escape from France. Robert Klein is a selfish man, cynical and disinterested in everything that happens around him, until he discovers the existence of his namesake of Jewish origin, finding himself embroiled in a disturbing exchange of identities. 
Aided by a splendid screenplay with Kafkaesque implications, written by 
Franco Solinas
, 
Joseph Losey
 masterfully combines the themes of double, otherness and anti-Semitic persecution. 
Mr. Klein
 is a film as tense as a thriller, of great visual suggestion and strong allegorical value, aimed at transcending the historical contingency‚Ä¶

Title: Bob le¬†Flambeur
Text:
In Paris, Bob Montagne is practically synonymous with gambling ‚Äì and winning. He is kind, classy and well-liked by virtually everyone in town, including police inspector Ledru. However, when Bob‚Äôs luck turns sour, he begins to lose friends and makes the most desperate gamble of his life: to rob the Deauville casino during Grand Prix weekend, when the vaults are full. Unfortunately, Bob soon learns that the game is rigged and the cops are on to¬†him.
Action! ‚Äì Three Auteurs: In The Wavelength of Melville
Melville still hasn‚Äôt come to his own entirely, but you can still see some traces of its future brilliance on display here. Also, whether it was intentional or not, the director would be setting up a lot of the things that would later become the French New Wave, so by default, it would not be wrong to call this film ahead of its time.
The film has also been cited as an influence for other modern movies such as 
Ocean‚ÄôS Eleven
 and 
Hard Eight
, and in some ways, you can see it. It lacks the energy and snappy editing of the former, especially, but a lot of the premise of this‚Ä¶ 
more Jean-Pierre Melville‚Äôs 
Bob the Gambler 
is a proficiently constructed crime film which significantly delivers a playful spiritedness. It's a prototypal example of the French New Wave movement as well as exhibiting a clear lineage to later films such as 
Ocean's Eleven
 and features some distinctly different camera angles and a soundtrack that incorporates an assortment of genres, from exotic jazz to more traditional accordion music.
Cinematographer Henri Decae does some tremendous work, and the atmosphere of Place Pigalle, a public square at the foot of the Montmartre hill, at daybreak is exquisite. It's this deeply romanticised view of the city that assists a very melancholic performance from Roger Duchesne (as Bob) in a fairytale-like storyline of a man discovering himself broke and thinking about one last heist. This film is stunning to look at and captures the magnificence of Paris in the mid-fifties. Early crime film from Jean-Pierre Melville, which the director himself called his "love letter to Paris". The opening showcases the city and introduces the title character. Bob is an aging compulsive gambler, who lives by night; one gamble to the next until he decides to take the ultimate gamble in the form of robbing a casino. Fortune favours the brave! The film is slow paced and effortlessly cool, Melville's attention to detail permeating every scene. The film favours visual storytelling over words, with the exception of Melville's own narration which chimes in at times. Bob le Flambeur is structured like a typical crime flick - planning a heist, one last score, crossed loyalties and an element of "cherchez la femme"‚Ä¶

Title: The Spy Who Loved¬†Me
Text:
Russian and British submarines with nuclear missiles on board both vanish from sight without a trace. England and Russia both blame each other as James Bond tries to solve the riddle of the disappearing ships. But the KGB also has an agent on the¬†case.
*Was a 
73
, now a 
100
* 
If you can't already tell, I've fallen head-over-heels in love with this movie, which isn't really a surprise considering I already had a strong response to 
The Spy Who Loved Me
 when I re-watched it initially back in January. I'm emerging from a Bond haze and yet another re-watch to write a little, if only to point out that *this* film is the ultimate installment from the series. For me at least. From the pre-credits sequence to the Bond song to Roger Moore and Barbara Bach and Richard fucking Kiel to the UNDERWATER LAIR and the stunts and the cars and the locations. 
The Spy Who Loved Me
 just has it all, you know?‚Ä¶ 
more "Moneypenny, where's 007?"
"He's on a mission sir. In Austria."
"Well, tell him to pull out. Immediately."
My favorite of the Roger Moore Bonds.
If you ever need proof for the theory that the Bond movies work as time capsules, transforming the formula to fit the tastes of the time, you need look no further than 
The Spy Who Loved Me
. It screams late 70's the same way the tacky special effects of the Brosnan Bonds scream late 90's. The cinematography is dark and stylized, imitating the neo-noir aesthetic of directors like Alan Pakula (
The Parallax View
). The soundtrack is a blend of funky slide guitar and early synth, marking the height of disco's popularity. There's even an undefeatable character‚Ä¶ 
more M here again. As you were. Been pulling some overtime here to catch up. 
The Spy Who Loved Me
 is everything you want out of a Bond film and is nearly flawless. Though the plot seems oddly familiar and has absolutely nothing to do with the book from which it is based, there is a ton to enjoy and the tropes are operating to perfection. With memorable music and characters, this film will be tough to beat. What follows is my mission debriefing, I hope you enjoy.
The Opening

Title: The Meyerowitz Stories (New and¬†Selected)
Text:
An estranged family gathers together in New York for an event celebrating the artistic work of their¬†father.
Noah Baumbach‚Äôs work is like piano music. It takes two points, whether those points be birth and death, love and hate, New York and LA, and examines the in between. It‚Äôs comprised of small moments, small notes, each providing a singular mood that, when put together, combines into a larger, more spastic piece. But there‚Äôs precision to that. These notes aren‚Äôt thrown together at random, one note always goes hand in hand with the next in a melodic way. It‚Äôs a series of different notes played from the same piano, each making it obvious through their sound that they come from the same instrument. It‚Äôs why when ‚ÄòThe Meyerowitz Stories‚Äô ends with a piece with strings, you feel the difference. These once singular sounds blend into something grander, something warmer. A newly-found sense of togetherness. "If he's not a great artist, that means he's just a prick." Gerwig's influence on Baumbach cannot be understated. This has almost every staple of his earlier work (primarily the male existential anxiety and familial fallout) but there's a sharpness to the editing rhythm + compositions and a kindness in the writing, a maturity and generosity that deepens the characters and comedy where the anger and cruelty of his earlier efforts would've undermined them. Performances are uniformly excellent of course but Elizabeth Marvel nearly walks away with this.

Title: Eureka
Text:
In rural Japan, the survivors of a tragedy converge and attempt to overcome their damaged selves, all while a serial killer is on the¬†loose.
The first film I've seen recently that I can confidently declare to be, not just one of my favorite films of all-time, but from a thematic // atmospheric // technical // emotional // sonic // imagistic // literary // formalist // structuralist standpoint, one of the greatest films ever made. A hauntingly gorgeous 3.5+ hour directorial tour de force that demands every second of its sprawling runtime, and explores the subject matter of post-traumatic stress disorder -- as well as a multitude of other psychological topics -- more effectively than any other film of the 21st century aside from maybe Bela Tarr's 
Werckmeister Harmonies.
 I am in awe; I am marveling, and I am moved beyond the point of being‚Ä¶ 
more 99%
Its a meditation on trauma.
We never see the bus jacking. We don‚Äôt know the mans motives for doing such a heinous crime. We only see it‚Äôs devastating psychological impacts on 3 damaged survivors. This is not a story about victims, this is the story of moving on. This is a story of recovery. This is the story of human triumph over darkness.
As equally bleak as it is hopeful, it‚Äôs generally a tragedy but it never feels overtly negative about the circumstances these characters that are built on loss are placed in. Rather it‚Äôs a languid and quiet piece. Yet despite its pacing, it doesn‚Äôt feel boring but rather it emits a therapeutic sense.

Title: Viridiana
Text:
Viridiana is preparing to start her life as a nun when she is sent, somewhat unwillingly, to visit her aging uncle, Don Jaime. He supports her; but the two have met only once. Jaime thinks Viridiana resembles his dead wife. Viridiana has secretly despised this man all her life and finds her worst fears proven when Jaime grows determined to seduce his pure niece. Viridiana isn't a good person. She's barely a person. She may seem virtuous and humble but at the core there's a self-righteousness that's prideful and disgusting. Bunuel was a known Anti-Catholic. It's not in the subtext but in the overtures. At the surface, Viridiana is about a nun falling from the grace of God, but it's the characters around her who are pure. While Viridiana is busy isolating her thoughts, human animals are living in God's image. Unnecessary Shame compels her to divorce from the calling she once held sacred. Her "charity" is the beginning of her own undoing.
The beggars are heart of this film. They aren't good, they aren't bad, they just are. Humans doing as humans do.‚Ä¶ 
more i think he don't really like the rich and religion i'm not sure Catching Up with Bu√±uel
"I went through a great shock, I am only trying to recover."
Such a deeply cynical film that you can feel Bu√±uel's hatred for the fascist Franco dictatorship in the very texture of every frame. The world itself is a test of Viridiana's faith, continually confronting her with the darkest depths of humanity's sinful depravity, rewarding her conviction with nothing but more hardship, asking at every turn, "What about now? Do you still believe?" How is anyone supposed to have faith in such a corrupt and twisted world? The infamous dinner party scene becomes a microcosm of Spain's political environs: the bourgeois fascist state is a juvenile food fight where the guests have no respect for the house, where they trash the place, stuff their faces, and fuck in the corner, destroying everything in their irreverent bacchanalia. 
"I was so happy‚Ä¶ You ruined everything."
Luis Bu√±uel

Later that night, he gets a wake-up call from the ghost of his late Uncle Wayne, the hard-partying, legendary ladies‚Äô man who was Connor‚Äôs mentor. Uncle Wayne has an urgent message which he delivers through three ghosts who guide Connor on an eye-opening tour of his romantic past, present and future. Title: Intruder
Text:
The overnight stock crew of a local supermarket find themselves being stalked and slashed by a mysterious¬†maniac.
Scott Spiegal‚Äôs 1989 supermarket slasher jam hits so many of my sweet spots‚Äîthe setting (I worked in a closing supermarket in the late 90‚Äôs and I can relate to this), creative kills featuring incredible knb gloopy gore effects, meat slicer murder (!), campy camera tricks, and tongue planted firmly in cheek humor.¬†
One of the last gasps as far as 80‚Äôs slasher movies go, this adheres to all the tropes you‚Äôd expect but manages to always feel fresh/creative‚ÄîIt‚Äôs loaded with gore, everyone involved is clearly having a blast, and I can‚Äôt stress enough how much I adore the setting here... it just feels so recognizable and familiar. I‚Äôve seen lots of people cast this movie aside but nah... this 
IS

Title: Apollo¬†18
Text:
Officially, Apollo 17 was the last manned mission to the moon. But a year later in 1973, three American astronauts were sent on a secret mission to the moon funded by the US Department of Defense. What you are about to see is the actual footage which the astronauts captured on that mission. While NASA denies its authenticity, others say it‚Äôs the real reason we‚Äôve never gone back to the¬†moon.
LANDING ON THE MOON VLOG (GONE WRONG) (NOT CLICKBAIT) A Trip to the Moon 2: Book of Shadows Painfully boring, visually unappealing, tonally dull and remarkably low on tension, Apollo 18 is a space horror movie done in the found-footage style that misses its landing site by quite some margin. Heck, it never took off. A space horror movie almost seems intriguing enough just for the combination of genres alone and with a half-good premise that showed potential it's somewhat surprising that Apollo 18 manages to be so uninspired and run-of-the-mill. It tries, it uses the genre tropes and religiously follows the guide on how to make a found-footage film but ultimately to a fault, ending up as derivative drivel.

Title: The Third¬†Murder
Text:
A lawyer tasked with defending a robbery-and-murder suspect begins developing doubts about what truly¬†happened.
we as audience members are inclined to believe the images we are shown, if we see a character committing a murder, we know that they are the murderer, we are inclined to trust the film‚Äôs presentation of events as accurate, to assume that we are seeing the truth unfold, like we are somehow beyond the other characters in the atmosphere. the interesting thing about the third murder is how it makes you believe that you know the truth, and pulls the rug out from underneath you, making you question every frame you‚Äôve experienced so far, making you question what the film‚Äôs reality actually is. can you trust an image? A group of lawyers defend a man who committed a terrible crime in an attempt to save him from capital punishment. The case seems lost from the start because the defendant has not only pleaded guilty but also seems unreliable, it is difficult to know whether he is lying, making it up on the spot or failing to remember the facts accurately. However, as the investigation unfolds, Shigemori and his team realize that the thin line that divides his client from the others involved is blurred. 
Sandome no Satsujin
 is a story with many nuances, a dense tapestry that shows the complexity of mankind's search for justice and truth as well as the constant ethical and moral questions that we‚Ä¶ 
more Koreeda comes up with a legal court procedural this time around and explores the complexities of human psyche, moral ambiguity,¬†justice divide,¬†truth and perception with his typical humanistic touches. Similar to other movies of his, it stands out in terms of direction, cinematography, soundtrack and performances. The slow burn procedural keeps it intriguing during the first hour, but feels slightly repetitive and bloated in the later portions, dipping your engagement level at many places. Overall, it still ends up a good worthy watch.

Title: Kids¬†Return
Text:
Shinji and Masaru spend most of their school days harassing fellow classmates and playing pranks. They drop out and Shinji becomes a small-time boxer, while Masaru joins up with a local yakuza gang. However, the world is a tough¬†place.
on certain days i think this melancholy portrait of young blindly navigating the passage into adulthood is kitano's finest work - a delicate synthesis of the editing and mise en scene experiments of his previous films, applied to arguably the most layered character work of his career (only 
achilles and the tortoise
 comes close for me). 
boxing becomes not a central metaphor but the physical shape of the film's emotional weights - every punch struck (in or out of the ring), every physical pleasure indulged in or denied, the journey from youthful "prank" violence to its more permanent twin. 
and in all of it no image more tragic than their quiet cab driver friend's car, upturned in a roadside ditch at night. life.
a neverending battle between who i am and who i hope to one day be. 
feeling lost among a sea of people. 
do you see what i see?
do you like who you are?
do you, too, question why happiness seems so far?
...my tears are flowing.
life.
a roundabout where each lane leads to some unavoidable pain.
painted portraits of hurtful histories in every nook of my brain.
do your struggles look like mine?
do your mistakes sink their fangs into your psyche?
do you, too, often wonder "are they just like me?"
...i am tired of not knowing.
life.
where darkness can never fully stop beauty from blossoming.
we're still here despite the many happiness droughts. 
don't‚Ä¶ 
more I don't think I could've watched this film at a more pivotal moment in my life. It's also a film that's evaded me the longest out of Kitano's body of work. For that reason alone it feels almost past what you'd call coincidental, as if it's a direct message. One that truly affected me on a more personal note than ever before in the context of a Takeshi Kitano film. Man, It was tough feeling the desparity when I found the pressure, the hopelessness and the lack of purpose a highly relatable feeling in this film.¬†
It's also his first film after his near fatal motor accident and it's quite telling considering the main theme he's championed in this film.‚Ä¶

Title: Crimes of¬†Passion
Text:
Fashion designer Joanna Crane leads a double life. By night she is China Blue, a prostitute who‚Äôs attracted the attention of a sexually frustrated private detective, and a psychopathic priest in possession of a murderous sex¬†toy.
A hyper stylized, psychosexual neon cum puddle of a thriller with plenty to say about marriage, sexual politics, and religion. Ken Russell‚Äôs lurid LA giallo-esque sex romp features some of the snappiest perverse dialogue I‚Äôve ever heard, a fearless scorcher of a performance from Kathleen Turner (her best IMO) and Anthony Perkins destroying the screen as a dildo killer Preacher on the piss stained ultra sleaze streets of Los Angeles.
A non stop crazy, full speed ahead sexual tango with relationship topics that never feel heavy handed. Definitely one of my favorite Ken Russell jams, as well as a banger of a satire that screams expressionistic cult mayhem waiting to be discovered nightly when the clock strikes midnight. It just feels so right that a movie as ludicrously horned up as this one includes the onscreen credit ‚ÄúDirector of Photography - Dick Bush.‚Äù when cinephiles talk about modern mainstream movies not being horny/sexy enough anymore, this is exactly what they're nostalgic for. ken russell deconstructing post-60s american sexuality; dialogue consisting solely of puns, juxtaposing cis-hetero surburban ennui with hyperbolic libido, a man driven to madness by his christian mores contradicting his fierce eros. ultra-trashy and fun, but also thoughtful and brooding. adult sincerity by way of neon-gauze.

Title: Meshes of the¬†Afternoon
Text:
A woman returning home falls asleep and has vivid dreams that may or may not be happening in reality. Through repetitive images and complete mismatching of the objective view of time and space, her dark inner desires play out¬†on-screen.
There's a before and after effect with this film where its influence is so vast that everything from Kate Bush albums to Vertigo comic books wouldn't look the same if it didn't exist. A desperate cry for every woman trapped inside an image, and one of the most important films ever made with regard to internal expression written in formal dream logic. this is so, so many things but it is also totally thee ur-slasher in which dream and reality overlap and become indistinguishable and a Phantom figure projects from within and/or invades into a woman's home/space/body. the phantom is mirror faced, slipping into a specific man who is also herself, eliding the difference, figuring both as the Woman's pseudo-doubles in a space of destabilized identity that is all parts multiplicity, opacity, reflection, and gender confusion. the immediate Threat to the body inside/outside emerges in the knife, the dread of stalking/being stalked. murder/suicide, escape and imprisonment, in bodies in domesticity. the shadowed mirror figure laying the funerary flower, the woman dead by her own hand, which is the hand of the man,‚Ä¶

The many hardships, the loss of loved ones, the frequent air raids of the enemy, nothing alters her¬†enthusiasm‚Ä¶

Title: Greenland
Text:
John Garrity, his estranged wife and their young son embark on a perilous journey to find sanctuary as a planet-killing comet hurtles toward Earth. Amid terrifying accounts of cities getting levelled, the Garritys experience the best and worst in humanity. As the countdown to the global apocalypse approaches zero, their incredible trek culminates in a desperate and last-minute flight to a possible safe¬†haven.
I have to admit, considering how low my expectations were for a Gerard Butler's end-of-the-world movie going in, GREENLAND definitely exceeded my expectations and boy was i surprised. Despite following some disaster movie cliches, this is a cut above most in this genre. A solid, well-directed & gripping movie, that manages to wring out a lot of tension and exhilarating bleakness from a very familiar premise. It's really grounded & subdued, focused more on characters rather than CGI spectacle, basically the antithesis of what the disaster genre has become. Even the performances are not caricature-ish or over-the-top, they feel very grounded with Gerard Butler giving one of his finest performances in years. Nothing like a good ol‚Äô disaster to save your marriage. After the hellscape of a year that was 2020, it stands to reason that a disaster movie about a regular guy and his family trying to stay alive as the world goes to shit around them would feel redundant and/or too close to home. Either way, it seems like something that wouldn‚Äôt be worth paying for when you can get the real thing for free by looking at your window, turning on the TV, or ‚Äî and this one is extra fun ‚Äî just thinking about literally any single aspect of your life as it‚Äôs been since March.
And yet it‚Äôs precisely because Ric Roman Waugh‚Äôs mid-budget ‚ÄúGreenland‚Äù eschews Hollywood expectations of its ‚Äúcraggy man vs. a planet-destroying comet‚Äù premise‚Ä¶

Title: Do Not Expect Too Much from the End of the¬†World
Text:
On behalf of a multinational company, a production assistant drives around the Romanian city of Bucharest, interviewing various citizens who have been injured due to work accidents to cast one of them in a ‚Äúsafety at work‚Äù¬†video.
Hesse and I just interviewed the writer/director of this incredible movie, Radu Jude, for MM, so PLEASE watch this before our interview drops...
At a time when most big American directors are fleeing into depictions of the past, here is a film that claustrophobically and hilariously foregrounds the abject shittiness and obscenity of being alive in the present day. This is like the Romanian Ulysses, a work that fixes you in the horror, vulgarity and ultimately heroism of getting through ONE DAY of being alive. Cannot recommend highly enough. Locarno Film Festival 2023 #6
Uwe Boll. TikTok. Matsuo Bash≈ç. Ernst Kantorowicz. Zoom. Andrew Tate. Handwritten end credits. A Godardian reappraisal of a Romanian film from 1981. A belated spritual sequel to 
The Happiest Girl in the World
. Nina Hoss. 163 minutes of Radu Jude firing on all cylinders, taking aim at everything from Romania selling itself for parts to Western Europe and the limits of 
Charlie Hebdo
-style caricature ("Aren't you afraid they'll call you a Putinist?") to the intractable pervasiveness of anti-Romani prejudice, the dangers of Romanian roads, and the tendency of capitalism to blame its own failings on the spectral remnants of communism. A consistently hilarious, deeply troubling report from the end of the world, where we're all‚Ä¶ 
more Somehow the pi√®ce de r√©sistance of this film, amid its barrage of hyperliterary namechecks and coprolalia, is a callback to Dylan‚Äôs Subterranean Homesick Blues. And when it comes up, it‚Äôs both riotous and annihilating. It‚Äôs the ULYSSES of Romanian cinema.

Title: Vice
Text:
George W. Bush picks Dick Cheney, the CEO of Halliburton Co., to be his Republican running mate in the 2000 presidential election. No stranger to politics, Cheney‚Äôs impressive r√©sum√© includes stints as White House chief of staff, House Minority Whip and Defense Secretary. When Bush wins by a narrow margin, Cheney begins to use his newfound power to help reshape the country and the¬†world.
VICE is an *incredibly* damning portrait of Dick Cheney, in that verrrrry few people could inspire a movie this bad ‚Äî this self-satisfied, this tonally incoherent, this misjudged ‚Äî and *still* not have it rank among the 10 worst things they‚Äôve ever done.
Adam McKay was an ‚Äúimportant" filmmaker until the moment he started trying to become one. i have endless faith that he‚Äôll figure things out, but these recent history disaster satires (disastires?) aren‚Äôt it. There are of course pieces of this that are funny and clever and maybe even occasionally startling...look man, it's hard to argue that it isn't at least engrossing. But don't be fooled, just like THE BIG SHORT this is another McKay film about how you aren't mad enough or informed enough, not as smart or caustic or active as you should be. The idea that nobody knew Dick Cheney was evil human garbage consumed by the pursuit of power and/or money and was responsible for the "legal" taking of, what, how many untold thousands of lives (an accusation it literally directly levels at the audience) is, to put it mildly, completely fucking smug and condescending. I guess we were collectively‚Ä¶

I loved the performances, I actually dug how unsubtle it is, despite some messiness and a few cringey scenes I‚Äôm sorry to say that I genuinely enjoyed this.

About halfway into 
Drunken Angel
, a white flower is thrown in the swampy lake stretching out like some eerie omen in the middle of the neighborhood. The rotten water opens its mouth and yawns in the mud-brown stillness ‚Äì but the flower stays on the surface. After all, your life is no deeper than a puddle. Drunken Angel

Title: The Flavor of Green Tea Over¬†Rice
Text:

(Re)finding love in the simple pleasures of life. What has been will always have happened but it doesn't define what will be. Understanding. A surprisingly light Ozu that may surprisingly be a favorite just in how honest it is to lived experience and how optimistic it is to continual healing, something he's certainly known for at large but here is it especially an ode to compassion. Loving each other during calm waters is easy, natural even, but it is in those moments of seeing each other during the tempest that are hard and, as such, dear.
The best time to have started change has passed. The second best is now. I was really worried about these two until they finally poured that green tea over the rice "It's enough. I'm glad you understand." So says Mokichi (Shin Saburi) to his wife Taeko (Michiyo Kogure) towards the end of 
The Flavor of Green Tea Over Rice
‚Äîand that line right there not only summarizes Yasujiro Ozu's view of marriage as contingent on compromise and empathy, but also succinctly sums up the great Japanese filmmaker's complex, unsparing yet wise humanist perspective as a whole. Just when you think Ozu, after putting the Satakes' troubled arranged marriage under an alternately comic and dramatic microscope for about an hour and a half, is about to succumb to bitterness and cynicism, he surprises us with a scene overflowing with tenderness and love. 
Without acceptance lies loneliness. Whether the initial passion was there or not, "reliability" is what inevitably keeps a marriage going. Someday the young ones will learn.

Title: The Mourning¬†Forest
Text:
A young woman working at a retirement home takes an elderly man living there on an excursion into the countryside, but the two wind up stranded in the titular¬†forest.
Using work as a distraction, life as a distraction, distractions as distractions, to push away the things we don't currently have the emotional energy to confront. It's easy to believe that we'll get to it soon, in the near future, one day, eventually, right after we finish dealing with whatever's immediate. But somehow there never seems to be the 'right time' nor the right amount of emotional energy we thought we'd have to deal with what we already should've. At least that's how I operate.
Breaking through that mental wall is somehow infinitely easier when experiencing, by proxy, that same 'coming to terms' but for somebody else; two different people with two different traumas finding shared healing through a shared experience. There is really no way to talk in greater detail about the film without delving into the greatly-personal, at least for me. Maybe I will in a comment, in someone else's review. Everything onscreen is so tangible, you can really hear the wind, feel the texture of the bark on the trees with your fingers, smell the disturbed earth. This is truly a beautiful experience. A mesmerising thing. I almost hesitate to call it a film since it feels like it‚Äôs on another plane of existence. Beautiful and spiritual, elegiac and cathartic, hopeful and quietly devastating. It conjured up so many often conflicting emotions in me that I hesitated to give it the full stars in fear I‚Äôd lost the true power in the meshes of my brain, but I think varying reactions is the intention. It‚Äôs a film about grieving, what a strange beast it is, the introspective exploration of yourself in time of crises and to a larger extent, life itself.

Title: Kill Bill: The Whole Bloody¬†Affair
Text:
Quentin Tarantino‚Äôs complete cut combining Kill Bill: Vol. 1 and Vol. 2 follows The Bride, a former assassin who awakens from a four-year coma after being shot by her mentor and lover, Bill. She embarks on a vengeful quest to eliminate Bill and the Deadly Viper Assassination Squad who betrayed¬†her.
Regal Pyramid Mall Cinemas, Ithaca, NY
October 10, 2003
I drove a black Saturn SL1 to the mall. The car belonged to my girlfriend, although we were broken up at the time. This is relevant because we weren‚Äôt apart long and would eventually spend the rest of our lives together. We were in college, she in Baltimore, me in Western New York. How I got the car amidst ‚Äúthe break‚Äù is beyond me. Her dad owned it, technically, I was just the boyfriend. But I was happy to have it. So I drove to the mall for a date I‚Äôd circled in red pen on the calendar. 
I went with my friend Mox, a fellow Tarantino allegiant. We‚Äôd seen the‚Ä¶ 
more Let's face it, there really isn't a better way to watch "Kill Bill" than this. It was originally envisioned as a massive, four hour action epic, complete with full color massacre scenes, until Tarantino declared that it was too long for mainstream audiences and decided to split it into two. To make things worse, the MPAA refused to give Kill Bill a desired R rating because of the ultra bloody scenes. To compromise, Tarantino made the offending scenes black and white, to make the blood less pronounced (I guess) and since then, the original uncut version has been all but lost.
But apparently they do still show it at festivals, and Tarantino has plans to bring the full cut to‚Ä¶ 
more I've got a lot wrapped up in this emotionally. It's a foundational moment in one of my very best friendships, and VOL. 1 came out just a couple months after I started working at Scarecrow, just full to bursting with references to movies I was just beginning to learn how to love. At the time, I thought I'd been waiting my whole life to see KILL BILL. Then I waited almost the same amount of time again to see this version, which is just incalculably great and the only way it should ever be watched. Even the makeshift home version you can cobble together if you have the right discs doesn't hold a candle to the real thing. While I was watching it at the Vista last night it was the best movie I have ever seen, and certainly the screening was one of the best moviegoing experiences I have ever had.

Title: The Marriage of Maria¬†Braun
Text:
Maria marries a young soldier in the last days of World War II, only for him to go missing in the war. She must rely on her beauty and ambition to navigate the difficult post-war years¬†alone.
Maria Braun is a product of survivalism. Reduced by war and loss to a struggle just to eat and breathe, she becomes a hardened soul. It's easy to suggest that she is Germany through Fassbinder's eyes (and perhaps this is so), but I think of her more as symbolic of any people under capitalism. She becomes ruthless and materialistic. The love of her life is a memory to her, regardless of his vital state, and her motivations, whatever they were before the marriage and war, become about advancing financially more than anything else. To her, love is to be pushed aside, to be manipulated, to be controlled. Even in her most compassionate moments, she is driven to violence.
That she‚Ä¶ 
more I confess it difficult for me to scrape my feelings and thoughts about 
The Marriage of Maria Braun
 into an articulate audit, much less one worthy of its due. My first encounter with Rainer Werner Fassbinder, I‚Äôm ashamed to admit, far exceeded my tepid expectations‚Äîthis film transfixed me, ransacking my subconscious while I was under its spell, and I stirred from its sorcery desolate, heartbroken and grieving.
Maria is a woman after my own heart, possessed by Hanna Schygulla in a commanding performance; a newlywed bride left alone to navigate the confusion of post-war Germany when her soldier husband, Hermann doesn‚Äôt return from his final mission. She haunts the dusty train station and rubble-filled streets waiting for her husband to‚Ä¶ 
more 86
Astonishing in how it captures a woman utilizing Post-War confusion for her personal gain, wrestling with moral/financial repercussions and an overwhelming rise in agency. But of course, it doesn't last. As Germany picks itself up, its interior rots from the core outward.

Title: L√©on: The¬†Professional

Title: The Joy Luck¬†Club
Text:
Through a series of flashbacks, four Chinese women born in America and their respective mothers born in feudal China explore their¬†pasts.

At first glance you might think "chick flick" but in reality, it is a drama and very impactful tear-jerking drama at that. If you want an emotional, mother-daughter dynamic movie, then this is perfect. I think anyone of any background can appreciate‚Ä¶ 
more Mother and daughter relationships always fascinate me because no matter what you tell yourself, some part of you is always craving that approval from your mother. No matter what you think, some part of you is always either trying to emulate or abandon her way of living.¬†
Every mother passes down part of herself to her daughter. Generations and generations of women are living and dying for their children. To give them a better life. To help them realize that they deserve to be seen. To help them realize their own value as a human being. And we aren‚Äôt perfect so we get it wrong sometimes and we hurt each other but that connection is always there.¬†
And in this‚Ä¶

Title: The Boy Who Harnessed the¬†Wind
Text:
Against all the odds, a thirteen year old boy in Malawi invents an unconventional way to save his family and village from¬†famine.
This would probably look like a pretty standard real-life inspirational story turned fictional movie, except that it's so rich and well-realized. The performances are terrific, and there's a lot of passion and emotion to the story. But what impressed me more was how thoroughly this film sinks into a local culture, capturing everything from the shifting tides of politics in a newly democratic environment to the unspoken presence of a cult that appears at transitional rituals like funerals. This is a very lived-in film, a convincing portrait of a society rather than the kind of glossy abstraction that comes out of so many based-on-a-true-story situations, and as a first feature, it's just stunning. Oscar-nominated actor Chiwetel Ejiofor originally planned to stay behind the camera in his solid but somewhat uninvolving directorial debut, but it‚Äôs easy to understand why felt he compelled to star: Trywell Kamkwamba is one of the more fascinating characters he‚Äôs ever played.
An uneducated Malawian farmer who strives to provide schooling for his children, Trywell is too dignified to sell the family‚Äôs ancestral land to the tobacco business, and too savvy to think he can redeem his future by surrendering his past. He‚Äôs an honest man in a village that‚Äôs being choked to death by corruption, and ‚Äî as a national food crisis takes hold ‚Äî Trywell grows too desperate to see that his young son William (Maxwell Simba) might‚Ä¶

Title: Rampage
Text:
Primatologist Davis Okoye shares an unshakable bond with George, the extraordinarily intelligent, silverback gorilla who has been in his care since birth. But a rogue genetic experiment gone awry mutates this gentle ape into a raging creature of enormous size. To make matters worse, it‚Äôs soon discovered there are other similarly altered animals. As these newly created alpha predators tear across North America, destroying everything in their path, Okoye teams with a discredited genetic engineer to secure an antidote, fighting his way through an ever-changing battlefield, not only to halt a global catastrophe but to save the fearsome creature that was once his¬†friend. √ó
It can be misleading to call a movie ‚Äúcritic-proof.‚Äù When this critic humbly concedes that ‚ÄúRampage‚Äù is critic-proof, it‚Äôs not because the Rock could open a movie with a Rotten Tomatoes score of negative 12% and still cook up a small fortune. No, ‚ÄúRampage‚Äù is only critic-proof because it‚Äôs one of the few studio films in recent history that‚Äôs too hollow to support any critical thought. Trying to say anything of substance about this standard-issue spectacle is like mounting a flat-screen TV on a shower curtain. 
Reuniting the dream team that brought you ‚ÄúJourney 2: The Mysterious Island‚Äù and ‚ÄúSan Andreas‚Äù (the only 9.6 degree earthquake that anyone has ever slept through), ‚ÄúRampage‚Äù isn‚Äôt bad so much as it‚Äôs barely‚Ä¶
