Title: Radio¬†Days
Text:
The Narrator tells us how the radio influenced his childhood in the days before TV. In the New York City of the late 1930s to the New Year‚Äôs Eve 1944, this coming-of-age tale mixes the narrator‚Äôs experiences with contemporary anecdotes and urban legends of the radio¬†stars.
Woody Allen writes, directs and narrates this comedy-drama about the Golden Age of Radio and the family whose lives are framed by it, starring an ensemble cast including Julie Kavner, Michael Tucker, Mia Farrow, Seth Green, Josh Mostel and Dianne Wiest. 
This is one of Allen‚Äôs warmest and most nostalgic films, looking back on the time with a great deal of affection. He really manages to capture the spirit of the era, crafting a sweet and well observed series of interlinking stories that combine to produce a tapestry of memory and wistfulness. 
The Purple Rose of Cairo
 explored the collective magic of the silver screen, and here Allen looks at the similar sorts of ways that radio brought everyone together,‚Ä¶ 
more Woody Allen‚Äôs ‚ÄúRadio Days‚Äù aches with tenderness and tangibility. It‚Äôs a gauzy portrait of the past filtered through the lens of loves encountered on the way through life.¬†
According to Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs brother-in-law, the director used to watch ‚ÄúRadio Days‚Äù on repeat; claiming it felt to him like a ‚Äúhome movie.‚Äù
Kubrick, born in the Bronx, was only one borough removed from the Rockaway, Queens of ‚ÄúRadio Days.‚Äù ¬†The success with which the movie captures its particular time and place might very well have felt familiar enough that Kubrick saw it as much a film as a personal flashback.¬†
But ‚ÄúRadio Days‚Äù is far from just a documentary record. Allen resurrects the era through a vision shaped by his primary‚Ä¶ 
more remember in Mad Men when he said
¬†In Greek, ‚Äúnostalgia‚Äù literally means ‚Äúthe pain from an old wound‚Äù. It‚Äôs a twinge in your heart, far more powerful than memory alone. This device isn‚Äôt a spaceship, it‚Äôs a time machine. It goes backwards and forwards, it takes us to a place where we ache to go again.

Title: Drowning by¬†Numbers
Text:
Three generations of women who seek to murder their husbands share a solidarity for one another which brings about three copy-cat¬†drownings.
first film i've ever seen that plays out like an I Spy game :) numbers 1-100 appear in ascending order, either disguised in the background or the characters' dialogue, which helped to keep my scattered, internet-corroded brain engaged. not that audience engagement is necessarily Peter Greenaway's prime objective‚Äîthe more of his (eerily fascinating) work i watch, the more it becomes evident that he caters pretty exclusively to his own personal fixations, among them mostly being death/decay, loveless marriages, and unorthodox eroticism. we #GreenawayGroupies are having a normal one!! In Drowning by Numbers, director Peter Greenaway created another one of his naked, bizarre world where clothes are always optional, and women always take the central stage. With its symbolic feminist message set in a modern dank fairy tale, Drowning by Numbers is simply as thought-provoking as it's weird and dark.
Drowning by Numbers chronicles how the murder of one man leads to a sinister chain reaction in a visually stunning yet otherwise unconventional small town. With exquisite, colorful cinematography and set design, Greenaway ensured that the whole experience be a top-notch visual treat even without its twisted story. The motley crew of an array of different personalities also helps with the quirkiness of the story. The three female leads,‚Ä¶

wired: biting your partner on the ass next to a pile of dead cows on the side of the road in Drowning By Numbers 
usual Greenaway ‚Äî gorgeous, perverse, hilarious, depressing, utterly singular

I do not see any circumstance in which the systematic displacement of people and claiming of their land can be justified, making someone a second-rate citizen of their homeland, taking their water, electricity, and shelter, in case they may stand up to their oppressors.
As a documentary, it is well paced, shot, and edited, but what truly makes it special is its deeply personal tale of resistance. Basel is his parents‚Äô son through and through, the next in line in a family of activists, and it shows.‚Ä¶

Title: We Are the¬†Best!
Text:
Three girls in 1980s Stockholm decide to form a punk band‚Äîdespite not having any instruments, and being told by everyone that punk is¬†dead.
After multiple viewings, I feel like I can finally rank the kids of 
We Are the Best!
 in order of coolness:
3) KLARA
. Klara has the best hair and the best attitude, but her fealty to punk is so obsessive it almost looks like a conservative streak. Anyone who looks down on their older brother for listening to Echo and the Bunnymen can never be truly cool.
2) BOBO
. Deeply impressed by how Bobo has achieved the look and airs of a distracted Marxist professor at the age of twelve; I've been working on it for much longer and still haven't got it this right. She is very appreciative of Klara's brother's musical taste but does get distracted from the‚Ä¶ 
more Punk is born in the bathroom mirrors of outsiders looking for an identity and lives in every 13-year-old who thinks shouting angry words loudly enough can change the world or at least get a rise out of it. Punk is dead, long live punk.
"What's the name of that song?"
"'Hang God.' It's about hanging God because He's a fascist. It's a Christian song, though, because you have to believe in God in order to hang Him." i got into playing music in 4th grade when a music teacher let me escape into her room during lunches to teach myself songs on the piano when i didn't feel welcome amongst others, so i really related to the way these girls discovered a joy in starting their punk band as a refuge. and we've all had a kinda-shitty childhood friend like klara who you're always butting heads with even though they mean the world to you. enjoyed watching their strong moments of companionship even though i found it kinda frustrating at points (although true to life; when you're 13 (or 31) a crush on someone who likes the same shit you do can mean the world)

Title: Andrei¬†Rublev
Text:
An expansive Russian drama, this film focuses on the life of revered religious icon painter Andrei Rublev. Drifting from place to place in a tumultuous era, the peace-seeking monk eventually gains a reputation for his art. But after Rublev witnesses a brutal battle and unintentionally becomes involved, he takes a vow of silence and spends time away from his work. As he begins to ease his troubled soul, he takes steps towards becoming a painter once¬†again.
"What is praised today is abused tomorrow. 
They will forget you, me, everything." 
I am utterly incapable of writing a review for this film, so I am not even going to try. It would be a disservice to the film, and to Tarkovsky. This is what I like to refer to as biblical cinema; I don't mean that the film itself is religious - at times it is, though I would argue its themes are more spiritual than religious... what I mean is that it is the type of film that you can revisit throughout your life - in times of need, in times of stress, in times of sorrow, you can come to a film like this one, and‚Ä¶ 
more Seven episodes in the life of the titular medieval Russian icon painter, all of which add up to one of the most vivid and detailed cinematic depictions I've ever seen of the life of an artist. From naive optimism about human nature to an abject despair that leads him to swear off art-making for about 15 years, then finally a renewal of his passion with the help of a former monk and a young bellmaker (whose obsessive quest to finish a massive bell acts as a metaphor for the artistic process), Andrei Rublev‚Äîat least in Andrei Tarkovsky's interpretation of his life‚Äîremains consistently engaged with the world around him; in such a context, the moment where he pointedly wonders aloud if‚Ä¶ 
more ***One of the best 150 films I have ever seen.***
Thanks to the power and humanism of a gripping anti-war manifesto called 
Ivanovo Detstvo
 (1962) directed by Andrei Tarkovsky, his next epic project 
Andrey Rublyov
 had a considerable amount of high expectations from the Russian audience. Naturally, something that continues happening even nowadays, the film surpassed any possible human expectation, being the cinematic result a politically brutal and violent motion picture. The most obvious consequence was the film being prohibited by the Russian government for approximately three years, complicating a wider worldwide distribution while being subject to several edited versions mostly removing every scene involving profanity, its greatly predominant Catholic influence and the noticeably violent torture and battle sequences. Decades‚Ä¶

Title: Secret¬†Honor
Text:

The Ultimate Quarantine Podcast Movie: In which a deranged, isolated man captures his own mad ranting on tape for posterity without fear of delusion or disgrace. In this case, it's former President Richard Milhous Nixon, as portrayed by Philip Baker Hall. But where most analysis of the film‚Äîand of Nixon in general‚Äîzeroes in on the paranoia, resentment, rage, and monomania that consumed the man, there is potentially a more generous reading. Nixon, in the late 1970s, when this is meant to take place, was not yet seventy years old, still wild-eyed and rangy, his stooped posture and bellowing diction intact but banished to San Clemente. Nixon grew up poor and angry, intent on proving to the world that he could‚Ä¶

Adaptation
. Then 
Matchstick Men

National Treasure

By 2005, Cage was now 40 years old with ten years of commercial and critical success to speak for him. Him winning his Oscar in 1996 all the way through 
The Weather Man

... Here's where we challenge the conception that reviewing films from a political lens demands older films fit today's standards (ignoring everything wrong with that assumption to do so): yesteryear's status quo can sometimes capture something inadvertently. It's not about measuring something by anachronistic standards (my standards derive from Marx and Lenin, who were old hat by 1936, anyway). It's about understanding these films through a lens of the people they left out.
This film, however, accidentally captures a very real feeling, one that sadly lingers today.

Title: Seven¬†Chances

Like Buster Keaton would have such a hard time finding a wife... 99/100
A nearly perfect film, and for my money the only Keaton feature that sustains the invention and exuberance of his best shorts. For one thing, it's neatly divided in half, with the first 30 or so minutes devoted to precise, small-scale comedy (favorite bit this time: Keaton twice retrieving the lawyer's spectacles as the will is read and the page is turned to reveal the sum bequeathed, then transferring them to his own face when he can't believe it's $7 million) and the next 30 constituting the medium's greatest (mostly) foot chase. There's admittedly a tinge of sexism to the premise‚Äîit's hard to imagine a woman running frantically from hundreds of angry men in tuxedos being very funny‚Äîbut I can't hold that sort of relatively benign prejudice against the 1920's. For more, take a look at the 
Scenic Routes column

Title: Harlan County¬†U.S.A.
Text:
This film documents the coal miners‚Äô strike against the Brookside Mine of the Eastover Mining Company in Harlan County, Kentucky in June, 1973. Eastovers refusal to sign a contract (when the miners joined with the United Mine Workers of America) led to the strike, which lasted more than a year and included violent battles between gun-toting company thugs/scabs and the picketing miners and their supportive women-folk. Director Barbara Kopple puts the strike into perspective by giving us some background on the historical plight of the miners and some history of the UMWA. Preserved by the Academy Film Archive in partnership with New York Women in Film & Television in¬†2004. √ó
long live unions. no matter the outcome 40 years later, a group of the proletariat, labelled as uneducated and worth less than dirt, organised and fought a corporation for over a goddamn year for what was right. their bravery is raw and real and inspirational even today, because we still need unions and solidarity amongst the marginalised and working classes, to try and change anything. while the mines are mostly gone and the environment of America is nothing like what it once was, this proves that everyday people can come together and make a change, and that nothing is more powerful than a collective of human spirit. this made me cry my eyes out, a testament to the power of documentary filmmaking at its finest. It really is unfathomable to me that we just straight up do not teach the labor history of America in schools. Like nothing. You can go through an entire K-12 education in America without so much as learning what a union is. Truly one of the most propagandized societies in human history!

Title: The¬†Counselor
Text:
A lawyer finds himself in far over his head when he attempts to get involved in drug¬†trafficking.
75/100
Recipe for a movie that'll piss people off: Jacobean + Euclidean + Hegelian. Can't really fault anyone for hating this (Andrew O'Hehir just tweeted "
The Counselor
 isn't merely terrible. It may be the worst movie ever made"), but its pitiless anti-narrative played for me like a pure, uncut version of 
No Country
, one without the hand-wringing old men. Was only bothered by the philosophizing at first, when I (naturally) assumed it would be occasional and intrusive; once it completely took over the movie, with the entire supporting cast turning unapologetically logorrheic, rolling with it wasn't hard. 
"But what's the 
point
?!" Just a portrait of hubris, really. This'll sound kinda bizarre, but 
The Counselor
 is essentially the same story as‚Ä¶ 
more "We will not be diminished by the brevity of our lives."
"When you cease to exist, the world that you have created will also cease to exist."
I've never fully bought into McCarthy's mercilessly cruel & fatalistic worldview, but something about the aggressively masculine, contradictory and primal existentialism he wanders here, as unsubtle as it is, is deeply fascinating to me. And accompanied by some of Ridley Scott's most vivid, richly detailed mise-en-sc√®ne & a lush sense of style that can explode with grotesquerie when required, capturing the way money is used as a bad paint job on a world that more closely resembles a garbage dump filled with corpses. It's like an evil little cousin to 
No Country for Old Men
,‚Ä¶ 
more on second thought maybe I won't pursue a life of crime

Title: Peppermint¬†Candy

sol kyung-gu plays a character emblematic of his country‚Äôs deteriorating autocracy, in one of the best performances i‚Äôve ever seen. the delicate seams of his career and marriage unraveling over time, paralleling the failing economic state of south korea in the 80‚Äôs and 90‚Äôs. inveigled by the masculine climate of a militarized society, our anti-hero, yeong-ho becomes increasingly volatile as a saga of misfortunes ensues, each more distressing than the last.¬†stripped of hope, yeong-ho seals his fate in front of an oncoming train. told through reverse chronology, director lee chang-dong uses¬†the metaphorical train to elucidate our protagonist‚Äôs ceaseless suffering, ploughing on a self-destructive path.

Title: Shoah
Text:
Director Claude Lanzmann spent 11 years on this sprawling documentary about the Holocaust, conducting his own interviews and refusing to use a single frame of archival footage. Dividing Holocaust witnesses into three categories ‚Äì survivors, bystanders, and perpetrators ‚Äì Lanzmann presents testimonies from survivors of the Chelmno concentration camp, an Auschwitz escapee, and witnesses of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising, as well as a chilling report of gas chambers from an SS officer at¬†Treblinka. √ó
Well, this is one way to spend your entire Saturday Had to be broken into two viewings due to the duration and difficulty of subject but previously I had only seen clips in college, mostly with regard to the economic visual craft of the interviews when we were studying documentary form, so I‚Äôm glad I finally took the time to sit through all 9.5 hours of it. Through a combination of minutely, horrifyingly detailed first-hand accounts of the torture and genocide of Jews during the holocaust (from victims, witnesses and perpetrators) and tranquil contemporary footage of the locations, landscapes and architecture that was once home to them Lanzmann creates this quiet, routine, ghostly mood around the act of witnessing (theirs and ours) and a major work of historical documentation. Title: St.¬†Vincent
Text:
A young boy whose parents just divorced finds an unlikely friend and mentor in the misanthropic, bawdy, hedonistic, war veteran who lives next¬†door.
Spoiler alert, Bill Murray has a stroke in this completely fictional movie and I nearly cried. 
When Bill Murray dies I'm not leaving my bed for a month. Sentimentalism, whether in large or small doses, isn't my type of thing. 
St. Vincent
 is definitely sentimental, and it's cliche, predictable, and corny at every possible beat, but the heart and the wisdom of this tale is earnest. Even with the sappiness, the film weaves a story that general audiences will eat up, and what can I say against that? There's much worse they could be viewing this weekend. 
Bill Murray steals the show, and he's the only reason why I kinda enjoyed this. Funny, cocky, and in love with portraying the smart ass; Murray is relishing every minute in a role that might garner Oscar buzz. 
Overall, It's recommended, solely on Murray's work, but if you enjoy some sappy entertainment; this is the film for you. Vincent: You never seen Abbott and Costello? 
Oliver: No, sir. Are they old? 
Vincent: No. They're dead. That's the oldest you can be.
A heartwarming and funny film about a crotchety older man and the boy that he babysits, St. Vincent is odd and endearing in all the right ways. I love this movie and watch it every few years (just to keep it fresh). Love Bill Murray's dry Bill Murrayness, Melissa McCarthy's straight-man, and I want to squeeze Jaeden Martell‚Äôs Oliver. This movie makes me happy and I cry every time. (read more 
here
)

Title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and¬†Evil
Text:
A visiting city reporter‚Äôs assignment suddenly revolves around the murder trial of a local millionaire, whom he¬†befriends.
the lady chablis MVP Based on non-fiction work of John Berendt, Clint Eastwood's Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil is a strange but fascinating southern gothic part courtroom drama. Eastwood's direction is very laidback and far more concerned with mood and colourful characters than actual plotting or murder. The milieu/atmosphere and eccentricities of the city are the best part of the film. John Cosack is good, Lady Chablis gives a scene stealing performance and Kevin Spacey is just playing himself. Based on a true crime story! What makes this film intriguing has nothing to do with the murder, it has everything to do with its colorful characters! And I kid you not these characters exist in real life!
The lovely, flamboyant trans woman Lady Chablis whom just happens to play herself in the film!
Luther Driggers the man whom walked around with flies buzzing all around him (They were attached to him via string)! Oh yeah he also carries a vial full of poison just like he does in the film!
Minerva the local voodoo high priestess!
Mr. Glover the man walking a dead dog named Patrick!
I'm a sucker for strong character driven plots and this film is bursting at the seams with quirky, eccentric characters that don't just add flavor to the story.. they are the story!

Title: Bad Day at Black¬†Rock

Macreedy, a WWII veteran with a paralyzed arm making an unscheduled stop in the remote desert town from which the film takes its name.¬†
The quietly hostile locals with a secret to keep don‚Äôt like strangers, particularly ones like Macreedy who don‚Äôt answer questions or respond to increasing levels of harassment. His arm and advancing years make him a seemingly soft target to town boss Robert Ryan and his gang of thugs, led by‚Ä¶ 
more There's of course a lot to be said for the expressive blocking; the aggressive beauty of the Lone Pines backdrop; the muscular moralism of the writing; the wizened professionalism of Spencer Tracy; Liz Wirth's heartbreaking near-last shot, a panicked face jutting into the sky's damning black void; and on and on. Persona
, Bergman followed it up with three lesser known masterpieces from 1968-69. The informal trilogy - 
Hour of the Wolf
, 
Shame
, 
The Passion of Anna

,‚Ä¶

Title: Threads
Text:
Documentary style account of a nuclear holocaust and its effect on the working class city of Sheffield, England; and the eventual long run effects of nuclear war on¬†civilization.
Hoop-Tober, Film 27 of 31:
I know for a fact that I will never watch this again, as it's probably the single most harrowing film I've ever seen. Beyond Come and See, beyond Salo, beyond Irreversible... more along the lines of how much Zero Day fucked me up because both subject matters are personally relevant; they're events that I fear, that could possibly - but god, I hope not - tie into my own life. Threads might be the first film I've watched that I wish the filmmakers wouldn't have checked their facts and gotten them right. But seeing as it played out in the same vein as Peter Watkin's 1965 masterpiece of a short film, The War Game (which‚Ä¶ 
more I was on the fence about nuclear holocaust before, but this film really turned me around! RIP E.T. This is the scariest movie. 
A kitchen sink drama plays out while an existence altering event whispers on radio and TV broadcasts in the background. By the time it's foreground, it's too late. The pieces are in place, the board is set, and everyone is thoroughly fucked. 
The tight framing (both literally and narratively) and liberal use of stock footage allows the filmmakers to present the idea of global catastrophe on what was surely a meager budget. Plenty of genre movies have imagined the post-apocalypse, typically set decades later or more and focused on action, heroes and villains. THREADS most powerful sections are depictions of the days just prior to and the decade following nuclear disaster. It's a film about‚Ä¶ 
more Needed something to cheer myself up today. One of the sole true anti-war films, where the aesthetics of conflict are stripped so bare of anything that could remotely be considered thrilling or exciting in favor of pure, raw brutality and unending suffering that will continue long after the camera stops focusing on the characters. Structurally perfect or near-perfect in its editing, performances, sound design, world-building, you name it. The most sophisticated depiction of misery you could ask for. jesus fucking christ, talk about a day ruiner Drop the nuke right on my fuckin head I do not want to live through this What a harrowing decent into a pure nightmare scenario. Bleak is an understatement... this intensly grim bad vibes nose dive into no hopesville goes all the way. You know, I always thought that nuclear war might be pretty cool but after watching this I'm starting to reconsider this position...
You go into a movie with the kind of reputation this one has ready for the misery and anguish but I was still somehow pretty surprised at how sudden this makes its transition from BBC-produced, kitchen-sink domestic drama TV movie (one you could picture them hiring Ken Loach to do) to straight-up disgusting apocalyptic horror movie about the minute procedural detail of being in the vicinity of a nuclear bomb, including graphic levels of detail and texture you can practically smell. Deploying gruesome docudrama recreations, archival footage, still photos and bluntly-stated facts/statistics on not just the immediate aftermath‚Ä¶

Title: Leviathan
Text:
In a Russian coastal town, Kolya is forced to fight the corrupt mayor when he is told that his house will be demolished. He recruits a lawyer friend to help, but the man‚Äôs arrival brings further misfortune for Kolya and his¬†family.
One of the sincerest films I've ever seen, a quality earning it an immediate spot amongst my favourite films of all time.
Leviathan is a bleak condemnation of orthodox religion, the pettiness of self gain and the corruptive nature of power. It is a film that tells its story with an unrelenting and startling sincerity, something I greatly admire in any film, but done to the quality it is done here, it left me angry, melancholic, empty, moved and above all deeply impressed.
Director Andrey Zvyagintsev and his team have crafted a film that is paced astonishingly well and looks breathtaking. The cold, grey cinematography and the impeccable attention to detail in creating this slice of Russian life both add‚Ä¶ 
more I‚Äôve honestly never seen a movie with acting that doesn‚Äôt feel like acting. It‚Äôs like this movie just found a drunk chaotic family with issues and started recording all of their issues. It feels so insanely authentic to the point where you wanna cry just looking at them drown out their problems in any way they can "All power is from God. Where there's power, there's might."
God is great. God is good. But in our earthly realm often God is simply power, the entwinement of church and state making this a reality we stare at everyday.
But how does it come to this? This blatant corruption of religion and government through the covetous vultures that circle above? The same vultures who perch atop the hierarchical ladder which allow us illusory dreams of climbing it ourselves but peck at our fingers when we reach out above. Indeed, the structures are as stratified as they ever were, effectively feudal systems disguised as papier-m√¢ch√© republics. Lenin, Stalin, Khrushchev, Gorbachev, we may have moved on in time but we are‚Ä¶

Compared to Mungiu's masterpiece 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days, Graduation is visibly less hard-hitting thematically, this time focusing on the misfortune of a Romanian middle class family, who have to individually grapple with the moral dilemmas the society throws at them.

Title: Howards¬†End

A saga of class relations and changing times in an Edwardian England on the brink of modernity, the film centers on liberal Margaret Schlegel, who, along with her sister Helen, becomes involved with two couples: wealthy, conservative industrialist Henry Wilcox and his wife Ruth, and the downwardly mobile working-class Leonard Bast and his mistress¬†Jackie.

One likes what one likes, oftentimes without knowing why. Quality is important, to be sure, and can cut through antagonistic predispositions. But attraction is something ineffable and frequently inexplicable. You may not be able to say what it is you love about the object of your affection, but of that love you have no doubt.
For a long time, I couldn‚Äôt say precisely why I loved 
Howards End
. Perhaps it was its European literary vintage and the sheen of sophistication it offered. Perhaps it was the precision of the plotting, with threads interweaving and resolving like clockwork without seeming forced‚Ä¶

Title: Good¬†Morning
Text:
A lighthearted take on director Yasujiro Ozu‚Äôs perennial theme of the challenges of inter¬≠generational relationships, Good Morning tells the story of two young boys who stop speaking in protest after their parents refuse to buy a television set. Ozu weaves a wealth of subtle gags through a family portrait as rich as those of his dramatic films, mocking the foibles of the adult world through the eyes of his child protagonists. Shot in stunning color and set in a suburb of Tokyo where housewives gossip about the neighbors‚Äô new washing machine and unemployed husbands look for work as door-to-door salesmen, this charming comedy refashions Ozu‚Äôs own silent classic I Was Born, But . . . to gently satirize consumerism in postwar¬†Japan. √ó

Title: Moonfall
Text:

Even by the standards of an independently financed $146 million Roland Emmerich movie about the Moon falling onto the Earth, ‚ÄúMoonfall‚Äù (solid title!) is still breathtakingly stupid. Every line is stupid. Every reveal is stupid. Every inference that conspiracy theorists could save us all if only people would listen to what they have to say is stupid ‚Äî not stupid as opposed to being serious, but stupid in lieu of being smart. That slight yet pivotal distinction epitomizes the sheer joylessness of Emmerich‚Äôs latest mega-slog, which betrays the dumb fun promised by its marketing campaign in favor of a po-faced interplanetary pileup that unfolds less like a B-movie spectacle with a NASA-worthy budget than it does a blockbuster remake of‚Ä¶

Title: Catch-22
Text:
A WWII military pilot makes a valiant effort to be certified insane in order to be excused from flying missions. But there‚Äôs a¬†catch.
‚ÄúUnless I miss my guess, Captain‚Ä¶you‚Äôre out of uniform.‚Äù
Beautifully nonsensical and disjointed. One of the most well-utilized casts of all time. Wildly quotable. Increasingly ridiculous and hopelessly inescapable. A war satire like no other, as if 
Dr. Strangelove
 was shot from the POV of a boots-on-the-ground soldier. Probably sacrificing a lot of subtext from the novel in the name of marketability, but I don‚Äôt really care.¬†
‚ÄúYou traded my parachute for a bunch of statues?‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, no, point of fact‚ÄîI traded our diesel engines for the statues.‚Äù
Major Major. The Syndicate. Chocolate-covered cotton. The everlasting ubiquity of the military-industrial complex. This shit is absolutely hilarious to me, and so much of it is still just as prevalent in the‚Ä¶ 
more Catch-22
 is a mess. I'm fairly certain it's meant to be. Episodic, non-chronological, absurd, and surreal, from a distance it looks and feels like it's trying to be too many things. Somehow director Mike Nichols manages (for the most part) to make it all work astoundingly well.
Beginning with one of the funniest first hours I have ever had the pleasure to see, 
Catch-22
 parades its stars about in loosely-related vignettes highlighting the anti-war statement at the core of the story. From mess officers bartering parachutes to the locals (their original owners only noticing once they're in the air) to a too-brief cameo by a young Bob Newhart playing a character named Capt. Major (soon promoted to Major), the first‚Ä¶ 
more feels like the film in itself is a catch-22, you need to have read (and loved) the book to truly appreciate it but you won‚Äôt appreciate it (as much) BECAUSE you read the book.¬†

Title: Fruitvale¬†Station

this is still happening to this day
. All cops are fucking bastards. Ryan Coogler, a film school graduate and native of the Bay area, has crafted one of the most powerful and important debut films I've ever experienced. Title: Mad Max¬†2
Text:
Max Rockatansky returns as the heroic loner who drives the dusty roads of a postapocalyptic Australian Outback in an unending search for gasoline. Arrayed against him and the other scraggly defendants of a fuel-depot encampment are the bizarre warriors commanded by the charismatic Lord Humungus, a violent leader whose scruples are as barren as the surrounding¬†landscape.
The truly unique thing about the Mad Max franchise is how Max is less a character than a mythic figure, and how each film is less an entry in a continuing story and more a retelling of the myth of Max, with the details getting more extravagant and incredible as time goes on. It‚Äôs one of my favorite narrative conceits, and it works incredibly in this film, which is explicitly framed as the recollections of an old man, telling the story of the hero who saved him. Title: High¬†Sierra
Text:
Given a pardon from jail, Roy Earle gets back into the swing of things as he robs a swanky¬†resort.
"Mister, what does it mean... when a man 'crashes out'?"
as a portrait of a man escaping into himself, it's a sublime distillation of the early gangster movie. Bogart (and motherfucking *Pard*) are aces, as is Lupino with her eyelashes for days, but the accoutrement lets them down. the stuff with the crippled girl is thematically invaluable, but the hokum involved in setting it up and knocking it down is a bit much... stretches the innocence that Earle is looking for, and the redemption he's hoping to siphon from it. a lot of the small stuff doesn't connect, but Earle's slow tumble down the mountain (metaphorically speaking) is fine. 
mostly astonished by the speed with which Raoul Walsh gets things going... hurry up and wait, with some of the quickest fades in film history. a breakneck pace to let Earle self-destruct in slow-motion. ‚ÄúHigh Sierra‚Äù is Humphrey Bogart and Ida Lupino setting the stock standards for the next decade of noir. Also, it was Bogart‚Äôs genius excuse to make a whole film into ‚Äòbring your dog to work day.‚Äô¬†
Bogart‚Äôs turn in ‚ÄúSierra‚Äù as former bank robber Roy Earle blends the wild 30s Hollywood gangster spirit into a more nuanced portrait of an unsuccessfully reformed criminal.¬†Where movies made lawbreakers part of the rebellious cool of Americana in the decade prior, the cons were generally little more than archetypical tricksters. They had only foibles; not humanity. 
Bogart‚Äôs Earle is a wiseguy with a soul. And a cute dog (Bogart‚Äôs own; Zero). It‚Äôs Bogart taking everything he‚Äôd learned in the Warner gangster stable and imbuing‚Ä¶ 
more Marking the moment when the gritty gangster sagas of the 1930s began giving way to the romantic fatalism of 1940s film noir, High Sierra also contains the star-making performance of Humphrey Bogart, who, alongside top-billed Ida Lupino, proved his leading-man mettle with his tough yet tender turn as Roy Earle. A career criminal plagued by his checkered past, Earle longs for a simpler life, but after getting sprung on parole, he falls in with a band of thieves for one last heist in the Sierra Nevada. Directed with characteristic punch by Raoul Walsh‚Äîwho makes the most of the vertiginous mountain location‚ÄîRoy and Lupino‚Äôs Marie, a fellow outcast also desperate to escape her past, hurtle inexorably toward an unforgettable cliffside climax and a rendezvous with destiny.

Title: From¬†Hell

Title: After¬†Life
Text:
On a cold Monday morning, a group of counselors clock in at an old-fashioned social services office. Their task is to interview the recently deceased, record their personal details, then, over the course of the week, assist them in choosing a single memory to keep for¬†eternity.
to be part of someone's chosen final memory, their greatest happiness. the ultimate compliment. I'm a pretty happy-go-lucky guy. In general, I live for now and try not to concern myself with the past; I learn from my mistakes and move on with my life. At least that is what I always tell myself. Once in a while something like After Life comes along which makes me reconsider that which has come before.
There is honestly not a tonne to the film aside from the concept, and at times it even feels like a documentary since there are a lot of camera-facing, individual interviews, but the topic is a fascinating one. You are about to leave this Earth forever; what is that one memory you would take with you? You would lose all else‚Ä¶ 
more At the time I searched desperately, inside myself, for any memory of happiness. Now, fifty years later, I learned I was part of someone else's happiness. What a wonderful discovery.

Title: Tale of¬†Cinema
Text:
In Seoul, a suicidal student meets a young woman who decides to join him in his fatal gesture. Dong-soo, an unsuccessful filmmaker, spots a beautiful young woman, who happens to be the lead actress in the film he has just seen. Their stories will cross paths thanks to their love for¬†cinema.
An exchange only possible in a Hong Sangsoo film:
While attempting to woo an actress, a man tells her the movie she starred in was based on events from his own life.
The actress responds, "I don't think you really understood the film." A filmic life becomes a real life, except it goes too far. The film works partially on three layers that define its three act structure. There is the short film, the man reflecting on the film and trying to re-create it in some ways, and finally the revelation (perhaps a lie) that the man was already the reality reflected onto film. Either way, life repeats itself no matter what, and man will always make the same mistakes ‚Äì caught up in what was and how it could instead be. This was the film Hong introduced his now iconic zoom lens, and it‚Äôs a fitting element. Hong‚Äôs realities are just as artificial as his films; they reflect characters trying to manipulate‚Ä¶ 
more Tale of Cinema
 opens as a transgressive love story, with upsetting elements and pretentious arthouse stylings. It's a film of suicide stopped by snowfall. Then 
Tale of Cinema
 has the most seamless of segues and becomes a different thing altogether. This is a film about films. It's about the nature of filmmaking, the arrogance of it, the way you make it about yourself. Art imitates life, then life imitates art, this is the crux of 
Tale of Cinema
 and made all the more profound by the obvious nature with which the film is self-aware. Hong Sang-soo crafts his film in a manner which is spectacular due to its lack of spectacle. His refusal to cover up the contemporary, as many‚Ä¶

Title: Kotoko
Text:
Suffering from double vision, a single mother tries to take care of her baby in the grip of terrifying hallucinations. An award-winning novelist overhears her singing whilst riding the bus and the pair subsequently develop a volatile¬†relationship.
art can't "get" mental illness "right", i don't think, because obviously there is no singular mental illness and all art can really do is reflect back at you a gesture or a tone of voice or a behavior that you recognize from your own experience. this is obviously different for everyone ‚Ä¶ so ‚ÄúX gets mental illness right‚Äù are little more than a representation politics gold star unless rooted in a personal context.¬†
the particular sound that kotoko's razor blade makes as it rakes across her inner arm ‚Äî a dry, papery rasp ‚Äî this feels real. so does kotoko's inability to function as a worker, her struggle with the manual action of underlining a word on a page (this‚Ä¶ 
more "I need J-pop star Cocco to step on me, beat me up, dominate me, stab me with a fork, turn my face into a bloody steak" - Shinya Tsukamoto while conceiving this film, presumably.
Very intimate psychological assault with a working mother's anxieties and fears turning into very hostile and violent hallucinations where strangers attack her and her child is in extreme danger. Tsukamoto films this bleak breakdown (which involves her child being taken away from her and striking up a relationship with a novelist who lets her use him as a literal punching bag so she doesn't hurt herself and eventually being locked away in an institution) in unbearably claustrophobic and manic close-ups and doesn't let good taste get in the way of making her experience feel as harrowing as possible. You either got embarrassed watching a Paranormal Activity movie and have never forgiven "jump scares" or you parroted somebody else's opinion to sound like you know more about a genre you probably just don't actually enjoy very much. Title: Into the¬†Inferno
Text:
With stunning views of eruptions and lava flows, Werner Herzog captures the raw power of volcanoes and their ties to indigenous spiritual¬†practices.
Werner, I lava you. Werner Herzog, the singularly solemn-voiced German auteur who has been a major force in world cinema for almost 50 years, has forged his legend by laughing at death. A prophet of darkness and a showman who would bungee jump into hell so long as he could come back with the footage to prove it, Herzog has survived everything from the lifeless tundras of Antarctica to the impassably dark jungles of Peru; from the burning oil fields of post-war Kuwait to the raging anger of his best fiend, Klaus Kinski.
And yet, for all of the suicidal adventures that he‚Äôs survived with a droll smile, film‚Äôs ultimate daredevil seemed to have met his match when he was discovered by an upstart‚Ä¶ 
more I went 
Into the Inferno
 hoping for some hot magma action, but also slightly worried. When asked about tough guys in cinema, Roger Ebert once cautioned a reader to remember that Sylvester Stallone will probably die rich and happy in bed, while Werner Herzog will probably die parachute-jumping into an erupting volcano. There are moments of this globe-spanning vulcanology voyage where I couldn't help but remember that prediction. Sat on the lip of an active volcano in Antarctica with his friend, the scientist Clive Oppenheimer, Herzog says he sometimes wants to go down into it and get a closer look, but it would be - and he uses this rather un-Wernerish word - "silly". Oppenheimer agrees, saying later that Herzog‚Ä¶

Title: Dimensions of¬†Dialogue
Text:
Three surreal depictions of failures of communication that occur on all levels of human¬†society.
Dimensions of Dialogue portrays in a perfectly adequate, episodic manner:
1) The problems of lack of communication.
2) The erroneous mentality that is narrow-minded fundamentalism.
3) The ridiculousness of winning an argument with obstinate and invalid arguments.
People seem to forget it, but communication is one of the gravest and most abounding problems of modern society these days, and it has always been.
97/100 Three different tales about communication. The first one illustrates a distortion of evolution: the organisms continuously mix and create new species; this process continues until all of the species have reached their maximum potential and become the same. Here, however, the species aren't relating to Darwin's theory, but to the fact that our values converge to a dull, colourless unity. In other words, we're all born different, but at the end of the day, the mechanical repetitions of society mould us the same. The second tale can be labelled "Love and its residuals". A couple's in love, they mix and become a powerful, seemingly indestructible unit. Then again, a problem arises, and both parties start blaming the other in perpetuity.‚Ä¶

both a dedicated look into the USA as a 'nation' of multiculturalism that has long taken over and defined what this country actually is all about. and as vitriolic and perspicacious capitalism critique.
there's no better place than a large-scale franchise kitchen to tell such a tale. hierarchy, hatred, horrors - the daily hustle and bustle in the game. aggression is all present, always given from top to bottom. an all to well known world. 
Alonso Ruizpalacios creates a burlesque panopticon of society: the capitalist owner smelling 'sabotage' on every corner, enhancing his self-fulfilling paranoia via projective identification. the kitchen itself meanwhile is full of ambivalent characters, everyone fighting their own war: maniacs, manics, manipulators, machines. hispanics, blacks, gringos. addicts, right wingers, assholes, dreamers.

Si hay algo que "La Cocina" y "The Bear" nos ense√±an, es que la impresora de comandas es el villano principal de las historias ambientadas en restaurantes. "Me estoy volviendo loco, no puedo ni llorar en espa√±ol." 55 CHICKEN SALADS 55 LITERS OF COLA 55 LOBSTERS 100 UNDERCOOKED PIZZAS 100 DESSERT 100 TENDERS 100 MEATBALLS 100 COFFEES 55 WINGS 55 SHAKES 55 PANCAKES 55 PASTAS 55 PEPPERS AND 155 PIECES OF MEAT WITH CUM un momento de silencio para las pel√≠culas prometedoras que no saben aterrizar su final Si La Cocina hubiera tenido como enfoque principal explorar la masculinidad t√≥xica, habr√≠a sido brillante. Sin embargo, al tratarse de una pel√≠cula sobre los desaf√≠os de ser inmigrante y la idealizaci√≥n del sue√±o americano, resulta decepcionante. 
La idea de contar esta historia a trav√©s del mundo de la cocina es fant√°stica, y a medida que avanza la trama, el ritmo se vuelve ca√≥tico, creando una ansiedad extrema, lo cual tiene intenci√≥n y funciona bien. El problema surge cuando, al intentar abordar temas como inmigraci√≥n, clases sociales y roles de g√©nero (donde tiene varios aciertos), el personaje principal resulta tan INSUFRIBLE que nunca logras empatizar con √©l. Al contrario, termina reforzando los estereotipos del mexicano promedio como machista, mis√≥gino y violento, llev√°ndote incluso a simpatizar m√°s con el gringo. Es un gran concepto con momentos logrados, pero que al final deja un sabor bastante amargo. ‚ÄúHoy amanec√≠ chueco.‚Äù

‚ÄúDel alma, eso es m√°s dif√≠cil de enderezar.‚Äù

Title: Eat Drink Man¬†Woman
Text:
Retired and widowed Chinese master chef Chu lives in modern day Taipei, with his three attractive daughters, all of whom are unattached. Soon, each daughter encounters a new man in their lives. When these new relationships blossom, stereotypes are broken and the living situation within the family¬†changes.
Gving this one star lower than perfect because the opening cooking montage didn't last for literally two hours. There really aren't enough father/daughter movies out there. I wish there were more, because I don't realize how much I yearn for them until I accidentally stumble upon them. This was a real delight.
I didn't realize until after it ended that it was made by Ang Lee, and once I learned that it all made sense: the attention to detail, the wonderful atmosphere, the great narrative and performances, juggling of the tones, from outright comedy to restrained drama. If Ang Lee made food the way he makes movies, he'd be one of the best chefs in the world.

Zombie's angriest - and best - endeavor yet, as he capitalizes and mushes his own brand of depraved, slimy violence into something interior in motive. Nothing is plainly for viscera, and spectacle is a haunted daydream. Each ax swing and chainsaw rip is the endpoint seen through terror, death, and loss. Zombie no longer cares about pleasure or titillation (that doesn't mean he won't give it to you, of course), showcasing brutalized, exploitative guts *after* the final breath whispers out of someone's throat instead. Title: The¬†Killer
Text:

Is it as good as the original? Of course not. Does it look like an ugly cheap streaming movie? Unfortunately yes. Also yes, and that matters more It‚Äôs been more than 30 years since John Woo first came to Hollywood, and it often feels like he‚Äôs been looking for a way back to Hong Kong ever since ‚Äî or at least a way back to the iconic action filmmaker he was when he worked there in the ‚Äô80s and early ‚Äô90s. Orgiastically blending the muted cool of a Jean-Pierre Melville neo-noir with the explosive melodrama of a Martin Scorsese crime epic and the florid grandiosity of a Chinese opera, Woo‚Äôs elevated style clashed with the meat-and-potatoes ethos of American blockbusters (‚ÄúFace/Off‚Äù endures as a crucial exception, in large part because its story was as heightened as the way that Woo chose to tell it). The same ecstasy‚Ä¶

Title: Gates of¬†Heaven
Text:
A documentary about a pet cemetery in California, and the people who have pets buried¬†there.
I had a dog once. He died from gastrointestinal complications because he kept eating my shoes. I really miss you, Herzog. "There's your dog; your dog's dead. But where's the thing that made it move? It had to be something, didn't it?"
These words, by a woman who has just buried her dog, are spoken in "Gates of Heaven." They express the central mystery of life. No philosopher has stated it better. They form the truth at the center of Errol Morris' 1978 documentary, which is surrounded by layer upon layer of comedy, pathos, irony, and human nature. I have seen this film perhaps 30 times, and am still not anywhere near the bottom of it: All I know is, it's about a lot more than pet cemeteries.
-- Roger Ebert

Title: Landscape in the¬†Mist
Text:
Two Greek children embark on a journey to search for their father, who supposedly lives in¬†Germany.
Watching films like 
Landscape in the Mist
 is the main reason why I love this site so much. I don't remember the exact circumstances that led to my viewing of this film, but I know that without Letterboxd I never in a 
quadrillion years
 would of ever discovered that this film, or any similar to it (such as Tarkovsky's films), even existed. It's truly a beautiful thing. The fog swallows the scenes.
A road that does not end, only disappears into silence. Two children walk, small, fragile, carrying the rumor of a father who may never exist. The pilgrimage is not to him, but to the wound of his absence.
Silence governs them. I do not mean the gentle silence of sleep, but an oppressive silence, distant, faceless, inflexible.
Absent parents, authority off-screen, history weighing like an invisible hand. The world speaks only through pauses, through the void between words.
Innocence here is very brief, almost illusory.
It shatters not in spectacle, but in shadows, in ellipses. Trauma arrives in silence, its echo louder than the act itself. The camera insists not on the violence, but on‚Ä¶ 
more After a very exhausting and demanding early filmography, the master of stillness and mythical symbolism Theodoros Angelopoulos forms part of the international cinematographic melodrama that directors such as Giuseppe Tornatore (Nuovo Cinema Paradiso [1988]) applied in their films. Perhaps that could be the main reason that Angelopoulos, once again, gained such a massive international attention since his WWII epic O Thiasos (1975). Despite this, Topio Stin Omichli easily belongs to his Top 5 films and has still a very present trademark of his own. Incorrectly considered as a road movie instead of a "road-to-nowhere movie", its metaphysical power and cinematic beauty have still the utter power of offering several symbols to be interpreted, a haunting and subjective ending sequence, and‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Ladykillers
Text:
Five oddball criminals planning a bank robbery rent rooms on a cul-de-sac from an octogenarian widow under the pretext that they are classical¬†musicians.
need a group of friends like this (old woman included) One of the greatest physical comedy performances in cinema is achieved by a 76-year-old.¬†
That would be Katie Johnson in ‚ÄúThe Ladykillers,‚Äù who doesn‚Äôt let being someone‚Äôs gran stop her from carrying the entire movie on her back.¬†
Released in an era of slick heist flicks like ‚ÄúRififi‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Killing,‚Äù director Alexander MacKendrick dared to have a different type of take for the time: what if it‚Äôs not the robbers who were cool... but an old lady?¬†
And cool as ice Johnson is - not just in the face of mildly hardened criminals, but also to MacKendrick‚Äôs technically exacting directorial style.¬†
Really though, the hapless robbers should have known better. MacKendrick‚Äôs production design is ripped right out of the darkest crags of German expressionism. Granny was living in the lair of Dr. Mabuse this whole time.¬†
Part of 
Warm Fuzzies Winter
. The confliction between old fashioned and the slightly pretentious values of Britain with more contemporary ones was one of the critical components that Ealing comedies controlled with authority, and 
The Ladykillers 
is a crucial testimony to that. Directed by Alexander Mackendrick (
Sweet Smell of Success
) and starring Ealing regular Alec Guinness as the impressively devious and intimidating Professor Marcus, the leader of a crime ring.
It's furthermore inhabited with some great supporting actors including an early screen performance from Peter Sellers, and the studio, as usual, delivers the material with impressive delicacy and skill; earning its screenwriter, William Rose, a Best Original Screenplay nomination at the 29th Academy Awards. 
The Ladykillers
 is an excellent example of the prestigious and beloved studio firing on all cylinders with well-written dialogue and a succession of metaphors for the state of the British isles after WWII.

Title: Limelight
Text:
A fading music hall comedian tries to help a despondent ballet dancer learn to walk and to again feel confident about¬†life.
74/100
A coda and a beginning, flawed and brilliant in the very same way. Just a beautiful story of lost fame, with a simple camera pan of empty seats destroying my tear ducts. Light cast against shadow. Charles Chaplin would forever be a master, and 
Limelight
 proves it. Bone simple - just a straight shot to the heart, unafraid of big emotions. A movie in which Chaplin comes to terms with his own obsolescence while also exclaiming "madadayo!" The style is so direct and the mise-en-scene so stripped-down that it feels like it's taking place in a dream. With Chaplin, even the flaws are virtues - they're the things that make him Chaplin.
It's impossible to see Chaplin and Keaton together and not get goosebumps. The two of them spent several days together workshopping and rehearsing their big scene. To have been a fly on the wall... What do you want meaning for? Life is a desire, not a meaning. Desire is the theme of all life!
Limelight
, a deeply personal film Charlie Chaplin directed later in his career,¬†tells the moving story of an ill and deeply unhappy ballerina who is nursed back to both mental and physical health by a comedian whose years of glory are long behind him. While this movie was made after Chaplin had abandoned the persona of the Tramp, it never once fails to evoke the emotions characteristic of a Chaplin film: heartfelt laughter, followed by tears of affection, followed by more laughter and then by more tears.
With this film, Chaplin brilliantly combines his style as a director of the silent‚Ä¶

Pale Flower
), is as an assault on the senses. The film's staged-looking production design lends it a theatrical quality, heightening the surreal nature of the whole thing; the palace's big white columns, empty spaces, and plenty of dark corners provide a striking contrast to the film's colorful costumes and makeup, particularly Himiko's striking red dress. Title: The Music¬†Room
Text:
An aging, decadent landlord‚Äôs passion for music becomes the undoing of his legacy as he sacrifices his wealth in order to compete with the opulent music room of his younger, richer¬†neighbour.
If you want to know what Indians were like at any given point in time, the last thing you'd want to do is turn to Indian films to find out. Our films do not attempt to portray Indians; the characters are simply idle aspirations, images of what Indians would like to become, rather than portraits of who they are.
As 
The Music Room
 cuts to the face of a man sitting deathly still, and as he moves slightly to ask his servant which month it is, I felt profoundly moved. I wasn't yet moved by anything that was happening onscreen - that would happen in a few minutes. I was moved because, for the first time, I was watching Indians‚Ä¶ 
more 85
Yet another immensely moving life portrait by Satyajit Ray. Most similar in tone to 
Apur Sansar
, but progress is replaced by melancholy, a world fading away while new traditions and perspectives emerge. The spaces are luminous in how it radiates a shadow of self, not quite as how life used to be, but the mirage remains convincing enough. So much of how Satyajit Ray conveys the divide between old money and the hunger of the new generation, is seen in the vulgarity of contrast, and the gorgeous B&W imagery lighting up the remains of wealth, right on the precipice of crumbling towards oblivion. Chhabi Biswas as Huzar Biswambhar Roy is an astonishingly quiet performance, of stature and posture vs.‚Ä¶ 
more What really stands out in this classic drama is the brilliant craftsmanship of Satyajit Ray and the profound performance from Chhabi Biswas. It is emotionally- culturally- thematically rich and along with well observed nuanced detailings, they make the poetic visual narration all the more powerful and evocative.

When my dad died, I seized on writing a eulogy as my best chance to process his loss ‚Äî potentially messy and egoistic as it was, I could either make a florid spectacle of my grief or risk letting it fester inside me even worse than it was always going to. Jonah Hill is a filmmaker (among other things), and when his older brother Jordan suffered a fatal embolism in December of 2017, I suspect that Hill felt a similar instinct to express himself the best way he knew how.

more After having seen all his films now I think it is safe to say I really like Wheatley's filmmaking voice. After Down Terrace and Kill List, this pitch black comedy is once again set in Wheatley's Britain that seems to reside in a slightly off kilter reality.
Wheatley paces the script, written by the lead actors, perfectly. Title: An Inconvenient¬†Truth
Text:

watched this in my environmental sciences class and I can't tell you how many times the teacher stopped the movie to say "ok so this was made in 2006, so it's definitely worse now" I assume we sorted all this out?
Be sure to drink lots of coffee so you can take lots of pee breaks during the long padding scenes of Al Gore looking mournful as he drives his car, or walking mournfully through airports, or gazing mournfully out of windows, etc. I remember this being a cultural lightning rod when it came out. (As a teenager in a "global warming is fake" household, I had no interest in seeing it then.) Catching up with it now, I'm guessing that resonance was thanks solely to the urgency of its subject matter. As a call to action, it's noble. But as a movie, it's a very solid pamphlet. Director Davis Guggenheim awkwardly tries to construct an issue advocacy doc out of two disparate halves: a slideshow concert movie and a biographical profile of Al Gore. The latter strikes me as mostly superfluous‚Äîsure, he's led an eventful life, but it's of dubious relevance to the topic at hand‚Äîwhile the former's very Climate Change 101‚Ä¶

Title: Concrete¬†Utopia
Text:
The world has been reduced to rubble by a massive earthquake. While no one knows for sure how far the ruins stretch, or what the cause of the earthquake may be, in the heart of Seoul there is only one apartment building left standing. It is called Hwang Gung Apartments. As time passes, outsiders start coming in to Hwang Gung Apartments trying to escape the extreme cold. Before long, the apartment residents are unable to cope with the increasing numbers. Feeling a threat to their very survival, the residents enact a special¬†measure. √ó
South Korea‚Äôs entry to compete for next year‚Äôs Best International film is not what you‚Äôd expect, especially when compared to more traditional Oscar hopefuls, but that‚Äôs what makes it all the more exciting. 
A disaster dystopian film that focuses less on the spectacle of the former and more on the inevitable unraveling of the micro-societies that emerge from the ashes of the apocalypse‚Äî which all on paper is extremely interesting, but at times 
Concrete
¬†
Utopia
¬†feels like it itself is being engulfed by the sheer enormity of its ambitious story. Class welfare, social constructs, even its exploration of religious allegories sometimes prevent basic character development so it becomes difficult to fully feel invested.¬†
But it‚Äôs still one of the better disaster movies from the last few years (or more) and for that alone it‚Äôs still an exciting watch. CONCRETE UTOPIA tells a dystopian parable of class warfare on a massive scale. Its unveiling of the ugliness within humanity as a pure society of law & order is created isn‚Äôt subtle but highly effective in its execution. Phenomenal production design work with a powerful ending. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre alive, you can live‚Äù
Concrete Utopia 
is a great disaster film that explores housing, immigration, civilization and, mostly, how evil a human can get in desperate times. Despite dragging during the midpoint, the film successfully balances dramatic and humorous moments and has outstanding technical values.

Title: Leviathan
Text:
An experimental portrait of the North American commercial fishing industry through the lens of GoPro cameras placed on a fishing vessel off the coast of New¬†England.
Ever thought about how unsettling it would be to be lost out at sea in the middle of the night? The dark waves churning and slopping against your head as you try to keep afloat, the water rushing into your ears, your nostrils, your mouth.
Between the sloshing noises you may hear squawking somewhere. Is it overhead, or far away? North, west, east, south? We've lost all sense of direction by now. And like a passing helicopter that can't land to pick you up, the flocks of gulls merely carry forward, ignoring your plight as they have the freedom of flight.
Under your feet you sense the endless depths below, a world imbued in darkness where all manner of things‚Ä¶

Title: Seabiscuit
Text:

¬®You know, you don't throw a whole life away just 'cause he's banged up a little.¬®
Seabiscuit is one of those overly sentimental feel good movies that actually works thanks to its outstanding cast, its wonderful cinematography, its emotional score, its engaging story, and a horse with a piercing glance that can melt the hardest of hearts. The horse, Seabiscuit, doesn't actually make an appearance until at least an hour into the movie, but director Gary Ross does an impressive job of setting up the characters and establishing the setting. Title: The¬†Past
Text:
After four years apart, Ahmad returns to his wife Marie in Paris in order to progress their divorce. During his brief stay, he cannot help noticing the strained relationship between Marie and her daughter Lucie. As he attempts to improve matters between mother and daughter Ahmad unwittingly lifts the lid on a long buried¬†secret‚Ä¶
74/100
 (was 82)
Second viewing reveals the moderate extent to which the film's detractors are right and the overwhelming extent to which they are dead wrong. Part of the problem, as I noted in my initial review from Cannes, is that Farhadi keeps hammering his theme home via dialogue, which really made me cringe in the home stretch this time. ("Now I want to talk about the present. The past is gone." Clumsy translation, maybe, but still, c'mon, Asghar. We saw the title on the poster walking in.) But I was also mindful of the fact that more than one critic has charged Farhadi with misogyny. Which seemed insane, and in fact 
is
 insane‚Äîthat's not a word that should be‚Ä¶ 
more Yet another family drama wherein the master dramatist impresses you with his magnificent storytelling and characterizations. The way he manages to create a complicated web of crisis through a simple divorce proceeding and a mix of children belonging to different cultures and bloodlines is something extraordinary. The human nature gets explored in an intrinsic manner, be it the complexity of guilt or the impossibility of letting things go. The final shot with an ambiguous end beautiful sums things up. There's a good life, a bad life and there's a Farhadi life. I'll be praying for you if it's the latter. 
A gripping, deftly written, realism heavy drama that doesn't pull back any of its punches, 
The Past 
is an exquisitely crafted film that feels too real to be called cinema. Strapped with rivetting performances and directed with utmost precision, Asghar Farhadi's cerebral family drama handles a chock full of themes ranging from hidden agendas and marriage to family and suicide without ever being the least bit overwhelming. It's at times unnerving as it is unpredictable, following this seemingly simple story of a divorce between a husband and wife and the red herrings in their relationships that unveil in real‚Ä¶

Title: Gods and¬†Monsters
Text:
It‚Äôs 1957, and James Whale‚Äôs heyday as the director of ‚ÄúFrankenstein,‚Äù ‚ÄúBride of Frankenstein‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Invisible Man‚Äù is long behind him. Retired and a semi-recluse, he lives his days accompanied only by images from his past. When his dour housekeeper, Hannah, hires a handsome young gardener, the flamboyant director and simple yard man develop an unlikely friendship, which will change them¬†forever.
I want an app on my phone that clips scenes from this movie but it uses Siri as an input. Like ‚Äúthe part where ian mckellan is talkin about his boyfriend from the trenches splayed out on some barbed wire for a week and they cut to Brendan Frazier doing some ‚Äúain‚Äôt that how it be‚Äù Aw shucks face‚Äù and then the phone just gives it to me and I can send it to people Acts as both a critique of the Hollywood system and a study of the trauma and danger that lies within open homosexuality. It‚Äôs incredibly rare - hell, I can‚Äôt think of another American queer film - that is written, directed, and stars an actual gay person, so it‚Äôs surprisingly refreshing that there‚Äôs one from the 90s. Ian McKellen delivers his finest performance as the retired classic director James Whale, showcasing a stunning amalgamation of the emotional intensities and delicacies that come with age and sexuality. While this may seem like a shock, and it could be a personal matter, but I doubt I‚Äôve ever seen homosexuality portrayed this well on film with regard to the mentality and mannerisms of this character, making 
Gods and Monsters
 as special as it is. I watch a lot of queer cinema. Probably a disproportionate amount when I come to think of it but I've noticed that not too many have made their way into my most personal films.
I'm not exactly sure why that is. It'd be easy to say that in my formative cinematic years I had yet to shake off the last remnants of my gay self loathing but I think it was more than that.
I think the hopeless romantic in me didn't connect with the New Queer Cinema that was all the rage when I was falling in love with the silver screen. Its anarchic reaction to AIDS didn't sit well with my lofty, love at first sight proclivities. I‚Ä¶

Title: Batman: Year¬†One
Text:
A wealthy playboy named Bruce Wayne and a Chicago cop named Jim Gordon both return to Gotham City where their lives unexpectedly¬†intersect.
Bryan Cranston as Lieutenant Jim Gordon... *chef's kiss* i am so sorry i really cant stop watching these animated batman movies Batman: Year One
 is so faithful to its source material that it actually forgets that the cinematic medium provides its own set of tools, resources & opportunities to improve & elevate a written story to new heights and allow the fans to relive the experience in a more enriching fashion. It is a perfectly fine adaptation but not one that leaves a lasting mark.
Directed by Lauren Montgomery & Sam Liu, the film narrates two subplots unfolding concurrently, one concerning Bruce Wayne's transformation from man to myth while the other follows James Gordon's attempts to rid Gotham of crime & his department from corruption. However, only one character's story is actually interesting here and it isn't the titular figure.

Title: American¬†Symphony
Text:
Musician Jon Batiste attempts to compose a symphony as his wife, writer Suleika Jaouad, undergoes cancer¬†treatment.
Can't believe I got Maestro'd twice in one year. Jon Batiste is a very talented musician, there's no doubt about that. What bothered me was that in many moments, when his wife is hospitalized seriously ill, he is shown laughing and chilling by the pool and on the beach. Maybe the editing work is to blame for some of this, I don't know. It's really odd and I felt bad. But it's very special to see Suleika fighting for her life and following her husband's work. I'd love to see a documentary focused maily on her perspective of everything.
2024 Oscars | 96th Academy Awards So many interesting ideas in here, but it feels like the film never fully explores any of them.¬†
Batiste is undoubtedly a musical genius, but I can‚Äôt help but think the film would be better told through Suleika‚Äôs perspective. Watching her partner own the Grammys through a television screen was, to me, the most interesting part of the movie. The happiness you feel for someone you love achieving their dream. The regret that you can‚Äôt be there. The guilt of maybe wishing your partner were there for you instead of in Las Vegas. How does one cope with all of these feelings?¬†
The documentary is technically very well-made, which is both a blessing and a curse. You get some beautiful‚Ä¶

Title: Malcolm¬†X
Text:
A tribute to the controversial black activist and leader of the struggle for black liberation. He hit bottom during his imprisonment in the ‚Äô50s, he became a Black Muslim and then a leader in the Nation of Islam. His assassination in 1965 left a legacy of self-determination and racial¬†pride.
The
 cinematic epic of American Blackness. I'd say it belongs in the fucking Smithsonian, but that's a white man's museum for a white man's history. When the white girl at the college asks Malcolm X what she can do to help his people, he responds with a blunt "Nothing." Though Malcolm X would later come around on this idea, the context of that girl's question stands out. She precedes it by asserting that she's not a bad person despite what her ancestors did, and... it's not that simple. If your parents killed someone and stole their wealth, I would not argue that you stand trial for their crimes, but I would argue that the wealth they stole should be returned.
